datasetPresenter.name: bsalLakeKonstanz_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Bodo saltans strain Lake Konstanz, the closest known non-parasitic relative of trypanosomatids.
datasetPresenter.description: Bodo saltans is a free-living heterotroph found worldwide in freshwater and marine habitats, and it is among the closest bodonid relatives of the trypanosomatids. The purpose of a B. saltans genome sequence is to provide an 'out-group' for comparative genomic analysis of the trypanosomatid parasites, and to provide a model of the ancestral trypanosomatid to distinguish those derived parts of the parasite genomes (i.e., unique trypanosomatid adaptations) from those which are a legacy of the free-living ancestor. The 39.9 Mb genome of B. saltans strain Konstanz was sequenced to 170× coverage using Illumina HiSeq. The genome was assembled into 2,402 scaffolds (N50 = 31.5 kb) and includes 18,936 predicted protein-coding sequences.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruLister427_2018_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Trypanosoma brucei Lister strain 427 2018 sequenced with PacBio, scaffolded with HiC data and annotated with Companion
datasetPresenter.description:
DNA from T. brucei Lister 427 isolate, PN221 (Figueiredo et al., PLoS Biol., 2008), was sequenced with SMRT sequencing technology (PacBio) to ~100X coverage. The reads were assembled into contigs following the RS_HGAP_Assembly.3 workflow from SMRT Analysis v2.3.0, with default parameters. Contigs belonging to megabase chromosomes were then scaffolded based on genome-wide chromosome conformation capture (Hi-C) data. Chromosome names containing the label ‘core' refer to the diploid core region. Chromosome names containing the label ‘3A', ‘3B', ‘5A' or ‘5B', refer to the 3’ or 5’ haploid subtelomeric regions of the different chromosomes.
The annotation was generated with Companion, using the T. brucei TREU927 annotation as reference. In addition, VSG genes were annotated based on similarity to the available VSGnome dataset from the T. brucei Lister 427 isolate (Cross et al., Mol. Biochem. Parasitol., 2014). For more information, see Müller et al., Nature, 2018.

Siegel Lab Website: http://siegel-lab.de

datasetPresenter.name: tcruDm28c2018_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Trypanosoma cruzi Dm28c sequenced with PacBio Single Molecule Real-Time technology.
datasetPresenter.description:
Parasites
T. cruzi Dm28c strain epimastigotes were grown in liver infusion tryptose (LIT) medium supplemented with 10 % fetal calf serum at 28C; total DNA was extracted using the Quick DNA Universal kit (Zymo Research).

Sequencing
Long insert PacBio libraries were prepared and sequenced by the University of Washington PacBio Sequencing Services (Washington, USA). Three Single Molecular Real-Time (SMRT) cells were for sequencing runs yielding 601,168 raw reads. An Illumina MiSeq platform was used with a paired-end library (2×150 cycles).

Assembly
Open reading frames of at least 150 amino acids in length, between a start and a stop codon, were extracted using the getorf tool from the EMBOSS suite. These sequences were mapped using blastp against a database of kinetoplastid proteins from TriTrypDB using as cut-off an e-value of 1e−10. The database of kinetoplastid proteins consists of a curated collection of CDS from various species of the genera Trypanosoma (excluding Trypanosoma grayi and Trypanosoma rangeli), Leishmania, Leptomonas, Crithidia and Endotrypanum.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruTCC_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Trypanosoma cruzi TCC sequenced with PacBio Single Molecule Real-Time technology and Illumina methods.
datasetPresenter.description:
Parasites
T. cruzi TCC strain epimastigotes were grown in liver infusion tryptose (LIT) medium supplemented with 10 % fetal calf serum at 28C; total DNA was extracted using the Quick DNA Universal kit (Zymo Research).

Sequencing
Long insert PacBio libraries were prepared and sequenced by the University of Washington PacBio Sequencing Services (Washington, USA). Eight Single Molecular Real-Time (SMRT) cells were for sequencing runs yielding 751,460 raw reads. An Illumina MiSeq platform was used with a paired-end library (2×150 cycles).

Assembly
Open reading frames of at least 150 amino acids in length, between a start and a stop codon, were extracted using the getorf tool from the EMBOSS suite. These sequences were mapped using blastp against a database of kinetoplastid proteins from TriTrypDB using as cut-off an e-value of 1e−10. The database of kinetoplastid proteins consists of a curated collection of CDS from various species of the genera Trypanosoma (excluding Trypanosoma grayi and Trypanosoma rangeli), Leishmania, Leptomonas, Crithidia and Endotrypanum.

datasetPresenter.name: ldonCL-SL_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: PacBio genome sequence and annotation of a clinical isolate of L. donovani causing cutaneous leishmaniasis from Sri Lanka.
datasetPresenter.description: Complete assembly of the Leishmania donovani genome from the strain responsible for cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) in Sri Lanka. The CL-SL clinical isolate was derived from a skin lesion on the nose from a 28 year old male from the Vavuniya district in Sri Lanka. Biopsy samples were directly inoculated into Leishmania promastigote culture medium. Leishmania DNA for both Illumina and PacBio sequencing was derived from parasites that were passaged through mice to increase survival in visceral organs.

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_dbxref_GeneDB_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: GeneDB: The Sanger Institute Pathogen Genomics Database
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotations from GeneDB
datasetPresenter.description: The GeneDB project is part of the Sanger Institute's Pathogen Genomics activities. GeneDB provides reliable access to the latest sequence data and annotation/curation for organisms sequenced by the Pathogen group.

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_dbxref_TDR_Targets_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: TDR Targets Database of drug target prioritization
datasetPresenter.description: The TDR Targets database facilitates the identification and prioritization of drugs and drug targets. Using the TDR Targets database as a tool, researchers can quickly prioritize genes of interest by running simple queries, assigning numerical weights to each query, and combining these results to produce a ranked list of candidate targets.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_quantitativeMassSpec_Procyclic_Cell_Cycle_quant_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: T. brucei procyclic cell cycle proteome
datasetPresenter.summary: T. brucei procyclic cell cycle proteome
datasetPresenter.description:
Single-step centrifugal elutriation was used to produce synchronous G1-phase procyclic trypanosomes for proteomic analysis of the cell cycle. Trypanosoma brucei clone 29.13.6 procyclic forms were harvested at 9 different time points and labeled with TMT10plex reagents, pooled, subjected to high-pH reverse phase chromatography, fractionated, and run on a LC-MultiNotch-MS3. Three biological replicates were run with technical triplicates. RAW data files were analyzed with MaxQuant 1.5.3.8 with an in-built Andromeda search engine containing T. brucei brucei TREU927 from TriTrypDB release 26.0. Data was normalized using CONSTANd, an iterative proportional fitting procedure. Proteins were considered cell cycle regulated if they were detected in at least two biological replicates with a Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) > 0.7 or mean PCC > 0.7 if detected in two or three replicates, respectively, with a mean fold change > 1.3. If an abundance value was 0 or missing for all replicates at one timepoint, the value was "floored" to 0.01 during the fold-change search to prevent division by 0. This only applied to the 3 hour timepoint for Tb927.7.2600 and to the 10 hour timepoint for Tb927.2.5860/Tb927.2.5870.

Additional data exploration tools for this dataset were developed by the data providers and are available at http://134.36.66.166:8883/cell_cycle.

templateInjector.prop: 0.5 hrs; 3 hrs; 5 hrs; 6 hrs; 7 hrs; 8 hrs; 9 hrs; 10 hrs; 11 hrs

datasetPresenter.name: tcruCLBrenerEsmeraldo-like_massSpec_Lysine_and_Nterminal_acetylation_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: T. cruzi and T. brucei lysine and N-terminal acetylation proteomes
datasetPresenter.summary: Acetylation of lysine and N-terminal amino acids in T. cruzi epimastigotes, T. brucei procyclic forms, and T. brucei bloodstream forms.
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomic analysis of lysine and N-terminal acetylation in T. cruzi and T. brucei
Total and cytoplasm and nucleus enriched fractions were prepared from Trypanosoma cruzi CL Brener strain epimastigotes, Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 bloodstream forms, and Trypanosoma brucei 29.13 procyclic forms. Mitochondrion enriched fractions were also obtained from T. cruzi epimastigotes and T. brucei procyclic forms.

Protein samples were, reduced, alkylated, and trypsin digested. Peptides were vacuum-dried and cleaned using Zip Tip micro-C18 before analysis by LC−MS/MS on an Easy-nLC 1000 coupled to an Orbitrap Elite mass spectrometer (Thermo Scientific).

Mass Spectral analysis
MS spectra were evaluated using MASCOT 2.5 (MATRIX SCIENCE). Peptides were matched to T. brucei TREU927 proteins and T. cruzi CL Brener. Carbamidomethyl cysteine was specified as a fixed modification, with oxidized methionine and acetylation of lysine residues allowed. The results were further analyzed with Scaffold software (Proteome Software).

datasetPresenter.name: pconCUL13_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome Sequence and Annotation of Paratrypanosoma confusum CUL13
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome sequence and annotation for Paratrypanosoma confusum CUL13. P. confusum is a monoxenous kinetoplastid flagel- late that constitutes the most basal branch of the highly diverse parasitic trypanosomatids. It has typical promastigote morphology but also forms surface-attached haptomonads and amastigotes. Haptomo- nads form by attachment to a surface via a large bulge at the base of the flagellum, which is then remodeled into a thin attachment pad associated with flagellum shortening. Promastigotes and haptomo- nads multiply by binary division, and the progeny of a haptomonad can either remain attached or grow a flagellum and resume swim- ming.

Genome assembly was made with GS De Novo Assembler (Newbler) v2.9 using reads obtained on the Illumina MiSeq platform combining 3.4 million reads from a paired-end library (insert size, 0.4 kb; average read length upon trimming, 241 nt; 29× coverage) and 4 million reads from a mate-pair library (insert size, 1–8 kb; av- erage read length upon trimming, 255 nt; 34× coverage).

datasetPresenter.name: lpanMHOMPA94PSC1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome Sequence and Annotation of Leishmania panamensis MHOM/PA/94/PSC-1
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome sequence and annotation for Leishmania panamensis MHOM/PA/94/PSC-1.

454 was used to sequence to libraries generating a total of 4 million reads (~30X coverage of the genome). Additionally, a library of paired-end 100-bp Illumina reads was obtained and used for assembly validation and error correction. De novo assembly of the 454 reads by using Newbler, yielded 108 scaffolds with an N50 size of 674 kb, a total size of 30.9 Mb and 2.29% of N (~600 gaps). A total of 140 fragments could be oriented and contiguated into 35 pseudochromosomes by using ABACAS and the genome of L. braziliensis as a reference. RATT was used to transfer the gene models annotated in the L. major and L. braziliensis genomes to the L. panamensis pseudochromosomes.

datasetPresenter.name: ttheEdinburgh_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome Sequence and Annotation of Trypanosoma theileri isolate Edinburgh
datasetPresenter.description:
A genome sequence and annotation for Trypanosoma (Megatrypanum) theileri.

Trypanosoma (Megatrypanum) theileri was isolated from a primary cell culture derived from a cow from the north west of England. Trypanosoma theileri was cultured invitro as in (Mott et al. 2011) and genomic DNA was extracted using Qiagen DNeasy Blood and Tissue kit. Isolated DNA was sequenced using a five library Illumina approach at the Beijing Genomics institute (www.genomics.cn/en/index). High quality, filtered, paired-end reads were subject to assembly using ALLPATHS-LG (Maccallum et al. 2009, default settings). Unassembled reads were assembled separately using SGA (Simpson and Durbin 2012, default settings). The assembled genome of T. theileri was subject to gene model prediction using Augustus (Stanke et al. 2006)
Keith R. Matthews, University of Edinburgh, and Mark Carrington, University of Cambridge, are co-correpsonding authors and Principle Investigators for this project.

Assembly Date :: 2014
Assembly Method :: ALLPATHS-LG v. 2014
Assembly Name :: Tth v3
Genome Coverage :: 100.0x
Sequencing Technology :: Illumina HiSeq

datasetPresenter.summary: Genome Sequence and Annotation of Trypanosoma cruzi Dm28c 2017
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequence of Trypanosoma cruzi, strain Dm28c, sequenced with Pacific Biosciences SMRT technology using P5-C3 chemistry, with ~150x coverage, resulting in an assembly with 1,030 contigs.
datasetPresenter.history: organism name changed from Trypanosoma cruzi cruzi strain Dm28c to Trypanosoma cruzi Dm28c 2017

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_quantitativeMassSpec_Nuclear_Proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Nuclear proteome of T. brucei
datasetPresenter.description:
All experiments were performed with logarithmically growing trypanosomes at a cell density of less than 1•10^7 cells/ml. Label-free quantitative mass spectrometry of purified trypanosome nuclei and compared the protein enrichment against whole cell lysates identifying 764 proteins significantly enriched in purified nuclei.


Schematics of the procedure. 1x10^10 procyclic trypanosome cells were mechanically lysed with a POLYTRON® homogenizer (whole cell lysate, WCL). The insoluble cell fraction which includes the nuclei was separated from the soluble fraction via a sucrose cushion and further separated on a discontinuous sucrose gradient. Various organelles and cell fragments accumulate at the interfaces of the sucrose layers and are thus separated from the nuclei, which are found in the pellet fraction (NUC). A typical picture of an ultracentrifugation tube after centrifugation is shown on the right.

datasetPresenter.name: bayaB08-376_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Blechomonas ayalai B08-376 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The genome sequence and annotation of trypanosomatid Blechomonas ayalai B08-376 that was isolated from a flea (Siphonaptera).

datasetPresenter.name: ldonBPK282A1_Zhang_Visceral_vs_Cutaneous_Leishmaniasis_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome of two L. donovani isolates derived from visceral or cutaneous leishmaniasis patients.
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcriptome of Visceral vs cutaneous leishmaniasis isolates

Isolates
The cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) clinical isolate was derived from a skin lesion on the nose from a 28 year old male. The visceral leishmaniasis clinical isolate was from a bone marrow aspirate from a 53-year-old male with chronic fever, hepatosplenomegaly, low haemoglobin and seropositivity for rK39 anti-Leishmania antibodies.

Spliced Leader RNA sequencing
cDNA libraries were prepared using mRNA derived from axenic promastigotes (Pro), axenic amastigotes (Ax) and macrophage-derived amastigotes (Am) and RNA sequencing was performed on the two isolates. Libraries were sequenced using the Genome Analyzer IIx (Illumina) at the High Throughput Genomics Unit at the University of Washington to generate 36-nt long single-end reads. The SL RNA-seq data have been submitted to the GEO database under accession no. GSE48475.

Samples:
VL-Pro axenic promastigotes from the strain causing visceral leishmaniasis
VL-Ax axenic amastigotes from the strain causing visceral leishmaniasis
VL-Am macrophage derived amastigotes from the strain causing visceral leishmaniasis
CL-Pro axenic promastigotes from the strain causing cutaneous leishmaniasis
CL-Ax axenic amastigotes from the strain causing cutaneous leishmaniasis
CL-Am macrophage derived amastigotes from the strain causing visceral leishmaniasis

datasetPresenter.name: lpyrH10_Flegontov_Transcriptome_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of total- and polyA RNA fraction (LpyrH10)
datasetPresenter.summary: Illumina RNA sequencing of total and polyA fractions from Leptomonas pyrrhocoris H10
datasetPresenter.description:
The global and polyA transcriptomes of L. pyrrhocoris H10

This dataset contains two transcriptome fractions for Leptomonas pyrrhocoris H10: total transcriptome partially depleted of rRNAs, and polyA fraction. Leptomonas was cultured in the RPMI-1640 and M199 media (1:1 v/v), supplemented with 10% FBS and 20 mg/L hemin. Purified RNA was sequenced using Illumina methods.

datasetPresenter.name: lpyrH10_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leptomonas pyrrhocoris H10 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
The genome sequence and annotation of Leptomonas pyrrhocoris H10

Leptomonas pyrrhocoris is one of a few globally distributed species of monoxenous trypanosomatids which dissemination is facilitated by omnipresence of its Pyrrhocoridae hosts.

Sequence and assembly:

L. pyrrhocoris H10 isolated from the firebug, Pyrrhocoris apterus, in Czech Republic was used for genome sequencing. The genome was sequenced by combining reads of the 454 FLX (single reads and 3-5 kbp mate pairs) and Illumina HiSeq 2000 platforms (~0.43 kb and ~0.9 kb inserts, 100 nt paired-end reads). The genome assembly strategy involved: assembly of 454 reads with Newbler, manual gap closing using an in-house software for contig graph analysis, correction of 454 homopolymer errors using Illumina DNA reads and closing additional assembly gaps using Illumina HiSeq transcriptomic reads of polyA and total fractions. The genome of Leptomonas was assembled almost to chromosome level and contains 60 scaffolds (37x average coverage with 454 reads, maximum scaffold length 2,995,728 bp) with scaffold N50 of 910,096 bp and a total assembly length of approximately 30.4 Mb.

Annotation:
Augustus v. 2.5.5 was used for genome annotation based on a set of manually selected high-confidence gene models. Augustus annotation was further improved manually in several steps: first, transcribed ORFs >200 aa in length not predicted by Augustus were added to the genome annotation; second, gene models with translation start sites predicted in regions with no transcriptomic coverage were corrected based on RNA-seq data and alignments with orthologous genes from other trypanosomatids; third, frameshift correction step was performed using transcriptomic reads aligned to the genome. Spliced leader sequences and polyA tracts in transcriptomic reads were used to predict 5’ and 3’ UTRs boundaries, respectively. The longest UTRs were taken in each case.

datasetPresenter.name: lseyATCC30220_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leptomonas seymouri ATCC 30220 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
The genome sequence and annotation of Leptomonas seymouri ATCC 30220

Sequence and Assembly:
Leptomonas seymouri is a monoxenous (single-host) insect trypanosomatid of low host specificity, together with Leishmania spp. belonging to subfamily Leishmaniinae. Leptomonas seymouri isolate ATCC 30220 was obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC, Manassas, USA). The L. seymouri ATCC 30220 genome was sequenced with 100 nt paired-end reads using the Illumina HiSeq 2000 platform (Macrogen, Seoul, South Korea). Draft genome of L. seymouri was assembled with CLC Genomics Workbench v. 7.0 employing a De Bruijn graph-based algorithm with N50 of 70,646 bp and a total length of approximately 27.3 Mbp.

Annotation:
Augustus v. 2.5.5 was used for genome annotation based on a set of manually selected high-confidence gene models. Further analysis of the Augustus annotation included manual curation of predicted genes based on transcriptome sequencing data: removing start sites predicted in regions with no transcriptomic coverage, adding transcribed ORFs >200 aa in length not predicted by Augustus, correcting frameshifts and ORFs bridging assembly gaps.

datasetPresenter.name: _massSpec_Docampo_Contractile_Vacuole_Proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomic analysis of a T. cruzi CL Brener fraction enriched for contractile vacuoles and analyzed by one-dimensional gel electrophoresis and LC-MS/MS
datasetPresenter.description:
Trypaosoma cruzi epimastigote contractile vacuole proteome
The contractile vacuole complex contributes to regulatory volume decrease during hyposmotic stress. The roles of the contractile vacuoles in protists, extend beyond regulation of cell volume to regulation of Ca2+ homeostasis and transport of proteins to the plasma membrane.

Contractile vacuole purification and proteomic analysis
Epimastigote fractions enriched in contractile vacuoles were isolated using differential and gradient centrifugation. Protein preparations were separated on SDS-page and gel slices were treated with trypsin. Peptides were analyzed by LC-MS/MS on an Agilent 1100 capillary LC (Palo Alto, CA) coupled to a LTQ linear ion trap mass spectrometer (Thermo Electron).

Mass Spectral analysis
Raw tandem mass spectra were converted into mzXML format and peak lists using ReAdW and mzMXL2Other. Peak lists were searched using Mascot v1.9 software (Matrix Science, Boston, MA) and two databases were searched during peptide discovery. The first database (normal) was composed of T. cruzi gene annotations provided by GeneDB (GeneDB.org). A second decoy (random) database was constructed by reversing sequences from the normal database. EuPathDB mapped peptides to CL Brener, Esmeraldo-Like and Non-Esmeraldo-Like

Samples
contractile vacuole fraction, CL Brener: peptides mapped to CL Brener
contractile vacuole fraction, Esmeraldo-like: peptides mapped to CL Brener Esmeraldo-like
contractile vacuole fraction, Non-Esmeraldo-like: peptides mapped to CL Brener Esmeraldo-like

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Docampo_Acidocalcisome_Proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome of acidocalcisome fractions from Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 procyclic form parasites.
datasetPresenter.description:
Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 Acidocalcisome Proteome
Acidocalcisomes are acidic organelles conserved from bacteria to human cells that are rich in polyphosphate, a polymer of orthophosphate units linked by high-energy phospho-anyhidride bonds.

Acidocalcisome purification
Acidocalcisomes were isolated from Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 procyclic form parasites by density-gradient ultracentrifugation using iodixanol solutions. Electron microscopy of PCF acidocalcisome fractions showed round organelles of various sizes up to 200 nm in diameter. After SDS-PAGE of pellets and gradient centrifugation bands, and enzymatic digestion with trypsin, peptides were analyzed by LC-MS/MS



Mass Spectral Analysis
Data was acquired using an Agilent 1100 Capillary LC system. Raw tandem mass spectra were converted to mzXML files, then into mascot generic files (MGF) via the Trans-Proteomic Pipeline (Seattle Proteome Center, Seattle, WA). MGF files were searched using Mascot (Matrix Scientific Inc, Boston, MA) against separate target and decoy databases obtained from the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). The target database contained all T. brucei protein sequences and the decoy database contained the reversed sequences from the target database.

Samples
ACCS1 - acidocalcisome from experiment 1
ACCS2 - acidocalcisome form experiment 2

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Bastin_detached_intact_flagellum_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Intact flagellar proteome of procyclic form (Tb427)
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome of detached intact flagella from Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 procyclic form parasites. Peptides are aligned to T. brucei TREU 927.
datasetPresenter.description:
Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 intact flagellar proteome

Flagellar Isolation:
T. brucei 427 FLA1RNAi cell line was grown in the presence of tetracycline for 3-4 days to induce flagellar detachment. Flagella were mechanically sheared and purified through a sucrose gradient.

Proteomics:
Flagellar fractions from 5 different samples were "shaved" and trypsin digested. The resulting tryptic peptides were analyzed by nanoLC-MS/MS using an Ultimate 3000 system coupled to an LTQ-Orbitrap Velos. Raw spectra were analyzed using MaxQuant software with the Andromeda search engine against a database containing the Trypanosoma brucei 927 proteins (TbruceiTreu927AnnotatedProteins_TriTrypDB-4.1.fasta - 9826 sequences).

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_PF_BF_Ribosome_Profiling_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Procyclic and bloodstream form mRNA transcriptome and ribosome profiling
datasetPresenter.summary: Ribosome profile and mRNA transcriptome of the T brucei Lister 427 bloodstream and procyclic forms mapped to T. brucei TREU 927.
datasetPresenter.description:
Procyclic and bloodstream form T. brucei 427 ribosome profiling and mRNA transcriptome mapped to T. brucei TREU 927.

Cultured procyclic form (PCF) and bloodstream form (BF) cells were treated with cycloheximide to arrest translating ribosomes and harvested. For ribosome profiling, samples were treated with RNase and monosomes were purified using sucrose gradients. mRNA from undigested lysates and from the RNAse treated monosome fraction was purified and sequencing libraries were prepared from size-selected (26-34nt) fractions.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Naguleswaran_procyclic_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptomes of T. brucei culture-derived slender/stumpy bloodstream and early/late procyclic forms
datasetPresenter.summary: RNA-Seq analysis was performed on defined cultures of slender bloodstream forms, stumpy bloodstream forms and early and late procyclic forms.
datasetPresenter.description: Trypanosoma brucei brucei EATRO 1125, clone AnTat 1.1 This study provides the first transcriptomic data from cultures of four consecutive life-cycle stages of Trypanosoma brucei. As well as validating the use of cultured slender and stumpy bloodstream forms as alternatives to animal-derived parasites, in compliance with 3R principles, it provides the first comparison of the transcriptomes of early and procyclic forms and identifies new stage-regulated transcripts.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Gowthaman_Spliced_Leaders_rnaSeqSplicedLeaderAndPolyASites_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Bloodstream and Procyclic for spliced leader transcriptomes (927, 427)(2014)
datasetPresenter.summary: Spliced leader sites determined by RNA sequencing of SL sequence-primed cDNA libraries from in vivo T. brucei 927 procyclic and slender forms as well as a cultured T brucei 427 bloodstream form.
datasetPresenter.description:
Spliced leader sites for T brucei procyclic and bloodstream forms determined by RNA sequencing of cDNA libraries primed using the SL_2 primer3, which matches the 3' T brucei SL sequence.

Libraries enriched for the 5' ends of mRNAs were constructed from three biological samples of strain 927 (two PCF and one slBF) and one cBF sample from strain 427. In brief, RNA was prepared and cDNA synthesized using primer Random5. Second strand synthesis was primed using SL_2nd primer3, which matches the 3' T. brucei SL sequence. The sequencing library was generated by PCR using the primer Multi-PCR P2 and one of the RP_index_PCR_reverse primers.

All libraries were sequenced using Illumina GA II machines at the High Throughput Genomics Unit at the University of Washington to generate ~36 nt reads using the proprietary Illumina read 1 sequencing primer (Rd1 SP) for fragmented mRNA and ribosome profiling libraries, or a custom sequencing primer (SL_SEQ_Primer2) for the SL RNA-seq libraries, as well as the Illumina indexing sequencing primer (Index SP).

This Spliced Leader RNA sequencing data set is from the same study as the mRNA sequencing and ribosome profiling data set: Procyclic and bloodstream form transcriptomes and ribosome profiling.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_quantitativeMassSpec_Gunasekera_LS_SS_comparison_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Long slender vs short stumpy blood stage quantitative proteomes
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparison of the Trypanosoma brucei TREU927 long slender and short stumpy blood stage proteomes analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS.
datasetPresenter.description:
Using Stable Isotope Labeling of Amino acids in Cell culture (SILAC) in combination with mass spectrometry we determined the abundance of greater than 1600 proteins in the long slender (LS) and short stumpy (SS) mammalian bloodstream form stages relative to the procyclic (PC) insect-form stage.

Parasite Preparation:
Procyclic Antat 1.1 cells were SILAC labeled and harvested after 11 cell divisions. Bloodstream form cells were grown in rats (Wistar). Long slender cells were harvested at day three from non-immunospuressed rats, while short stumpy cells were harvested at day 5 from immunosuppressed rats.

Proteomic Analysis:
Two technical replicates were done each using 5 x 106 procyclic cells that were mixed with 5 x 106 LS or SS cells in Laemmli buffer and boiled at 95°C for 5 min. Samples were analyzed by 1 dimensional electrophoresis, trypsin digested and analyzed by LC-MS/MS.

Peptide Identification:
Mass Spectrometry data and SILAC ratio interpretation was made with MaxQuant version 1.1.1.36 run under Windows7 against a T. brucei sequence database (version available in May 2011) from the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute Pathogen Sequencing Unit. The default contamination database in Andromeda (MaxQuant) was searched together with the target database.

templateInjector.prop: Long Slender (LS) vs Short Stumpy (SS) blood stages

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_quantitativeMassSpec_Urbaniak_BSF_PCF_PhosphoProteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Quantitative phosphoproteomes of bloodstream and procyclic forms (Tb427)
datasetPresenter.summary: Quantitative phosphoproteomes of procyclic and bloodstream form Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 clone 29.13.6
datasetPresenter.description:
Quantitative Phosphoproteomic study comparing bloodstream and procyclic form Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 clone 29.13.6 using SILAC labeling of each lifecycle stage.

A 1:1 mix of procyclic form cells grown in light-SILAC media and bloodstream form cells grown in heavy-SILAC media (and vise versa) was solubilized with SDS and tryptic peptides were generated by FASP. Peptides were fractionated by SCX and enriched for phosphopeptides over TiO2 beads prior to analysis by liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry.

Data was processed using MaxQuant version 1.3.0.5. Proteins were identified by searching a protein sequence database containing T. brucei brucei 927 annotated proteins (Version 4.0, downloaded from TriTrypDB) supplemented with the VSG221 sequence and frequently observed contaminants (porcine trypsin, bovine serum albumins and mammalian keratins) to contain a total of 10,081 protein sequences.

SILAC ratios for phosphorylation sites were calculated using only data from the phosphoproteomic experiments, and SILAC ratios for proteins were calculated using only data from the nonenriched proteomic experiments.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Lott_MethylArgenine_Proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Methylarginine proteome of mitochondrially enriched procyclic form T. brucei 29-13cells
datasetPresenter.description:
The methylarginine proteome of mitochondrially enriched procyclic form T. brucei 29-13 cells was determined by LC-MS/MS.

Extracts of procyclic form T. brucei 29-13 cells were enriched for mitochondria and digested with Trypsin and GluC. The resulting peptides were analyzed by 2D, LC-MS/MS using alternating electron transfer dissociation (ETD) and collision induced dissociation (CID) to increase sensitivity for detecting peptides. The filtered dta files were searched using Sequest against the TriTryp database containing 11425 gene entries (ver 10-20-2010). In total, 1332 methylarginine residues in 676 proteins were identified.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Niemann_Mitochondrial_Outer_Membrane_Proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Fractionated Mitochondrial Membrane and ER Proteomes (427, 29-13)
datasetPresenter.summary: Protein composition of Trypanosoma brucei mitochondrial membrane and endoplasmic reticulum fractions
datasetPresenter.description:
Protein composition of Trypanosoma brucei mitochondrial membrane and endoplasmic reticulum fractions, including purified whole mitochondrial membranes (pure mitos), crude and purified outer membrane, crude inner membrane, crude endoplasmic reticulum, and mixed outer membrane/endiplasmic reticulum fractions.

Procyclic form T. brucei Lister 427 and 29-13 cells were lysed and fractionated in two separate experiments. The purification scheme is presented in the figure below. Samples analyzed in experiment 1 include
1. Purified mitochonria (pure mitos)
2. Crude outer membrane (crude OM)
3. Purified outer membrane (pure OM)
4. Outer membrane - endoplasmic reticulum mixture (OM/ER)

Samples analyzed in the second experiment include:
1. Crude endoplasmic reticulum (crude ER)
2. Purified mitochonria (pure mitos)
3. Crude inner membrane (crude IM)
5. Crude outer membrane (crude OM)
6. Purified outer membrane (pure OM)
7. Outer membrane - endoplasmic reticulum mixture (OM/ER)

For each sample, precipitated proteins were digested with trypsin and analyzed by LC-MS/MS. Mass spectrometric data from the two independent experiments were processed separately using the software MaxQuant (version 1.2.0.18). For protein identification, spectra were correlated with the Trypanosoma brucei protein database (TriTrypDB, version 3.1), containing 9826 protein entries, using Andromeda.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Read_Mitochondrial_Argenine_Methylation_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Mitochondrial Methylarginine proteome of T. brucei strain EATRO 164 Istar1
datasetPresenter.description:
The mitochondrial methylarginine proteome of procyclic form T. brucei EATRO 164 Istar1 cells was determined by LC-MS/MS.

Mitochondrial extracts from procyclic form cells were prepared from 1 x 1010 cells. Precipitated proteins were digested with trypsin or GluC. The resulting peptides were analyzed by 2D, LC-MS/MS using alternating electron transfer dissociation (ETD) and collision induced dissociation (CID) to increase sensitivity for detecting peptides. Bioworks 3.3.1 SP1 QF31448 (Thermofisher Scientific) was used to generate dta files. The filtered dta files were searched on Sequest Cluster 3.3.1 against the TriTryp database containing 11425 gene entries (ver 10-10-2010). This approach led to the comprehensive, sensitive and confident identification and localization of over 160 methylarginine proteins.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Urbaniak_BSF_PCF_PhosphoProteomics_RSRC

datasetPresenter.summary: Comparative phosphoproteomes of T. brucei 427 bloodstream and procyclic forms
datasetPresenter.description:
Phosphoproteomic study comparing bloodstream and procyclic form Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 clone 29.13.6 using SILAC labeling of each lifecycle stage.

A 1:1 mix of procyclic form cells grown in light-SILAC media and bloodstream form cells grown in heavy-SILAC media (and vise versa) was solubilized with SDS and tryptic peptides were generated by FASP. Proteins were identified by searching a protein sequence database containing T. brucei brucei 927 annotated proteins (Version 4.0, downloaded from TriTrypDB) supplemented with the VSG221 sequence and frequently observed contaminants (porcine trypsin, bovine serum albumins and mammalian keratins) to contain a total of 10,081 protein sequences.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_quantitativeMassSpec_Butter_Two_Stages_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Proteome of Procyclic vs Bloodstream forms by SILAC
datasetPresenter.summary: Quantitative proteomic analysis comparing procyclic to bloodstream form T. brucei MiTat 1.4 cells in a SILAC label-switch experiment.
datasetPresenter.description:
SILAC Proteomic analysis comparing procyclic and bloodstream form T. brucei MiTat 1.4 cells.

Procyclic and bloodstream form cells were separately grown in the presence or absence of heavy amino acids. Equal amounts (5 X 107 cells) of BSF and PCF trypanosomes were separately harvested by centrifugation. Cell suspensions of "heavy" isotope labeled BSF were mixed with "light" isotope labeled PCF and vice versa.

Proteins preparations were trypsin or LysC digested, separated by 1D--electrophoresis and eluted from 12 gel slices. Peptides were analyzed by nanoflow liquid chromatography on an EASY-nLC system coupled to an LTQ-Orbitrap XL (Thermo Fisher) and additionally to a Q Exactive (Thermo Fisher). Raw MS files were processed with MaxQuant 1.2.2.0 using standard settings and searched against the annotated protein database of Trypanosoma brucei TREU927 (TriTrypDB's version 3.3, 9826 entries) with the Andromeda search engine integrated into the MaxQuant software suite.

LysC_l v BSF_h;LysC_h v BSF_l;Tryp_l v BSF_h;Tryp_h v BSF_l;Combined_l v BSF_h;Combined_h v BSF_l

datasetPresenter.name: lamaMHOMBR71973M2269_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation of Leishmania amazonensis MHOM/BR/71973/M2269
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome sequence and annotation of Leishmania amazonensis MHOM/BR/71973/M2269
Leishmania amazonensis (MHOM/BR/71973/M2269 strain) was originally extracted from the cutaneous lesions of a patient from Cafezal city, in the state of Para, Brazil, in 1973. DNA sequences were obtained using the whole-genome shotgun strategy with a combination of 454 GS-FLX Titanium (2X coverage) and Solexa (94X coverage) methods. The final assembly was performed using Zorro, which combined scaffolds from Solexa and contigs from 454 sequencing to generate 2627 scaffolds (>1000 bp in length) that specified a genome size of 29.6 Mb.

This Leishmania strain is an international reference strain according to World Health Organization report on Control of Leishmaniases (2010).

This genome was annotated at EuPathDB using the Companion genome annotation pipeline.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: Please refer to the Genome Institute Data Use Policy for further information.

datasetPresenter.name: lenrLEM3045_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leishmania enriettii strain LEM3045 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome Sequence and Annotation of Leishmania enriettii strain LEM3045

The Leishmania enriettii LEM3045 (WHO strain identifier MCAV/BR/95/CUR3) was obtained from Professeurs Jean-Pierre Dedet and Patrick Bastien, University Montpellier, France.

Genomic DNA was prepared from nuclei isolated from parasites lysed using 0.5% NP-40, to minimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA, and was provided by Drs. Deborah E Dobson and Stephen M. Beverley, Washington University School of Medicine.

Total sequence coverage of Illumina instrument reads was 124X (fragments, 3 and 8kb) using a genome size estimate of 35Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the ALLPATHS software (Broad Institute). This draft assembly was referred to as Leishmania enriettii LEM3045 1.0.1. This version has been gap filled and cleaned of contaminating contigs. The assembly is made up of a total of 648 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 352kb (N50 contig length was 102.7kb). The assembly spans 30.4Mb.

This work was supported by NIH grant AI29646 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Institute at Washington University.

This genome was annotated using an annotation pipeline tailored to the kinteoplastids. The pipeline was developed by the Parasite Genomics team at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute and a publication on the subject is expected soon.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: Please consult with the Principal Investigator before undertaking large scale analyses of this unpublished sequence or annotation.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruTulacl2_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome Sequence of Trypanosoma cruzi Tula cl2
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome Sequence of Trypanosoma cruzi Tula cl2

The Trypanosoma cruzi Tula strain cl2 was obtained from Dr. Gregory Buck, Center for the Study of Biological Complexity, Microbiology and Immunology, Virginia Commonwealth University. This strain is a representative of the TcI lineage of T. cruzi. A clonal derivative was prepared from epimastigote culture by plating on blood agar plates (M. Lewis) and used for sequencing.

Genomic DNA was depleted for kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA (kDNA), which represents up to 30-50% of the total DNA in the cell, by Dr. Andrey Matveyev. In brief, total DNA was extracted from cultured late log phase T. cruzi Tula strain cl2 epimastigote forms and submitted to low voltage electrophoresis in 0.8% low melting agarose. The gDNA-containing agarose blocks were excised from the gel, leaving the kDNA networks intact in the gel. Purified gDNA was recovered from the agarose blocks after digestion using Beta-agarase I.

The gDNA was fragmented and sequenced using the Roche 454 FLX Titanium technology and a draft assembly was produced. Total sequence coverage from the Roche 454 technology was approx. 50X (fragments @ 22X, 3 Kb paired end (PE) @20X, 8 Kb PE @ 6.5X) using a genome size estimate of 40 Mbp. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the Newbler software (Roche 454). This first draft assembly was referred to as T.cruzi Tula_cl2_1.0. In the T.cruzi Tula_cl2_1.0 assembly 7727 scaffold gaps were closed with Illumina read mapping and local assembly. Assembly error correction was done by aligning Illumina reads to correct insertion and deletion errors (4624). Finally, 40 contaminating contigs were removed to yield version T.cruzi Tula_cl2_1.0.1. The T.cruzi Tula_cl2_1.0.1 assembly is made up of a total of 52,620 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 2.7 kb (N50 contig length is 2.1 kb) and assembled size spans 75 Mb.

This work was supported by NSF DEB-0830056 grant to Gregory Buck and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Institute at Washington University School of Medicine.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: Please consult with the Principal Investigator before undertaking large scale analyses of this unpublished sequence or annotation.

datasetPresenter.name: laetL147_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Genome Sequence and Annotation of Leishmania aethiopica strain L147
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome Sequence and Annotation of Leishmania aethiopica L147
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome sequence and Annotation of Leishmania aethiopica L147

The Leishmania aethiopica strain L147 (WHO strain identifier MHOM/ET/1972/L100) was obtained from Charles Jaffe (Israel). This parasite was isolated in Ethiopia in Wollega Province near to a place called Nekempti. It was obtained from a relapsing skin lesion of a 9-year old male, who was a classical case of diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis (DCL); his skin test was negative (as is typical for DCL). The excreted factor (EF) sub-serotype is B1. Other designations for Strain LRC-L147 are LV24 (Liverpool School of Trop. Med. collection number). (Strain information provided by Lee Schnur, Israel). PCR tests using primers recognizing both LRV1 and LRV2 were negative.

Genomic DNA was prepared by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to minimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA, and was provided by Drs. Natalia Akopyants and Stephen Beverley, Washington University School of Medicine. The input sequence coverage of Illumina instrument fragment reads was 110X, while the final assembled coverage was 220X (fragments, 3 and 8kb) using a genome size estimate of 35Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the ALLPATHS software (Broad Institute). This first draft assembly is referred to as Leishmania aethiopica L147 2.0.2. This version has been cleaned of contaminating contigs. The assembly is made up of a total of 472 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 552kb (N50 contig length was 38.5kb). The assembly spans 31Mb.

This work was supported by NIH grant AI29646 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Institute at Washington University.

This genome was annotated using an annotation pipeline tailored to the kinteoplastids. The pipeline was developed by the Parasite Genomics team at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute and a publication on the subject is expected soon.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Broadhead_Flagellar_Proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma brucei flagellum proteome comprising the membrane-bound axoneme and associated paraflagellar rod.
datasetPresenter.description: Trypanosoma brucei flagellum proteome The structural axoneme and associated paraflagellar rod and basal body were isolated from procyclic Trypanosoma brucei by a well-characterized procedure of detergent and high-salt treatment. Bands and spots were cut from one- and two-dimensional gels and digested with trypsin, and the resulting peptides analysed by reverse-phase high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with tandem mass spectrometry. Bands and spots excised from ten representative gels were analysed, resulting in the identification of 522 nonredundant proteins.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Cell_Surface_Stage_Proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma brucei proteomics of the cell surface from both PCF and BSF stages
datasetPresenter.description:
This study utilized surface biotinylation, coupled with affinity purification and shotgun proteomics, to obtain cell surface proteomes from procyclic (PCF) (insect midgut) and bloodstream-form (BSF) T. brucei. Comparison of surface proteomes from procyclic and bloodstream forms reveals extensive stage-specific surface protein remodeling that includes individual paralogues within protein families. In this study, endogenous GPI-specific phospholipase C (GPI-PLC) activity was used to release VSG from the cell surface prior to streptavidin purification of surface proteins.
Surface-biotinylated cells were fractionated into Lysate (L), Insoluble (I), Soluble (S), Unbound (U), and Bound (B) fractions

datasetPresenter.name: ldonBPK282A1_massSpec_Pawar_Pro_Ama_Proteomes_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: L. donovani MHOM/IN/80/Dd8 promasatigote and amastigote stage proteomes determined by searching and mapping the L. donovani MHOM/IN/80/Dd8 mass-spec peptides against the non-redundant protein database of L. donovani BPK282A1.
datasetPresenter.description:
Promastigote and amastigote stage proteomes of Leishmania donovani MHOM/IN/80/Dd8.

Samples and Mass Spec:
Promastigote and amastigote stages of L. donovani MHOM/IND/80/Dd8 were grown in axenic culture. Lysates from both life stages were prepared by two methods: SDS-PAGE fractionation followed by in-gel trypsin digestion and in-solution digestion followed by strong cationic exchange (SCX) chromatography fractionation. Fractions were analyzed by LC-MS/MS using LTQ-Orbitrap Velos ETD mass spectrometer.

Mass spectrometry data analysis:
Mass spectra were searched against the non-redundant protein database of L. donovani BPK282A1 (n = 8032) available from NCBI (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov) using Sequest and Mascot (version 2.2) submitted through Proteome Discoverer software (version 1.3).

The peptides are mapped against the L. donovani BPK282A1 genome.

datasetPresenter.name: ldonBPK282A1_massSpec_Jamdhade_promastigotes_glycosomes_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: L. donovani strain MHOM/IN/80/Dd8 promastigote glycosome proteome aligned to L. donovani BPK282A1.
datasetPresenter.description: Proteomic profiling using high resolution mass spectrometry of a sucrose density gradient-enriched glycosomal fraction isolated from Leishmania donovani MHOM/IN/80/Dd8 promastigotes. The L. donovani BPK282A1 protein database was used for database dependent searches of the glycosome mass spectrometry data

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_quantitativeMassSpec_Global_Proteome_Purine_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Purine Stress Response in Promastigotes- Quantitative Proteomics
datasetPresenter.summary: Quantitative proteomic comparison (AMT tag method) of purine-rich and purine-starved L. donovani promastigotes at 6, 12, 24, and 48h. Data are analyzed against the L. infantum JPCM5 genome.
datasetPresenter.description:
Quantitative proteomic comparison of purine-rich and purine-starved L. donovani promastigotes at 6, 12, 24, and 48h post starvation.

Leishmania donovani promastigotes were incubated in purine-rich (100 μM hypoxanthine) or purine-depleted conditions. Proteomes were compared by the label-free and ultra-sensitive proteomic accurate mass and time (AMT) tag method and analyzed against the Leishmania infantum JPCM5 proteome.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_quantitative_massSpec_Guther_glycosomal_proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Glycosome proteome for procyclic form Trypanosoma brucei by epitope-tag organelle enrichment. Green - high-confidence glycosomal.
datasetPresenter.description:
High-confidence glycosome proteome from Trypanosoma brucei procyclic forms. Bar colour represents confidence group: Green - high-confidence glycosomal (>8 sigma) Grey/white - possible glycosomal (3-8 sigma) Red- unlikely to be glycosomal (<3 sigma)

Methods: Wild-type procyclic form trypanosomes were grown in normal (R0K0, light) medium, and cells transfected to express GFP-tagged Pex13.1 were labeled with heavy (R6K4) Lys and Arg. The cells were mixed 1:1, and glycosomes were enriched by centrifugation, followed by affinity-selection on anti-GFP magnetic beads. Peptides from genuine glycosome components have high heavy/light isotope ratios, whereas those from contaminants have isotope ratios close to 1:1. The figure below outlines the approach taken by this study.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_quantitativeMassSpec_Quant_Tbrucei_Differentiation_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Quantitative proteomics of T. brucei differentiation
datasetPresenter.summary: Quant proteomics of Trypanosoma brucei AnTat1.1 differentiation with time points at 0, 2, 4, 6, 12, 24, and 48 hours
datasetPresenter.description: Trypanosoma brucei AnTat1.1 parasites were induced to differentiate from the short stumpy (SS) form to the procyclic form (PF) using 6 mM citrate/cis-aconitate. Parasites were harvested at 0, 2, 4, 6, 12, 24, and 48 hours after treatment, and established PF and long slender (LS) forms were also collected. After separation by SDS-PAGE, in-gel digestion and elution, and desalting, peptide fractions were separated by nanoflow liquid chromatography on an EASY-nLC 1000 system (Thermo) coupled to a Q Exactive or Q Exactive Plus mass spectrometer (Thermo). The label-free quantitative mass-spectrometry results were analyzed using the LFQ algorithm of MaxQuant. Raw files were searched agains the T. brucei TREU927 protein database.

datasetPresenter.name: lmajFriedlin_massSpec_Pawar_Pro_Proteomes_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: L. major ATCC 50122 promastigote proteome determined by searching and mapping against Leishmania major strain Fredlin.
datasetPresenter.description:
Leishmania major ATCC 50122 promastigote proteome.

Leishmania major ATCC 50122 promasatigotes were lysed and peptides were prepared by two methods: SDS-PAGE fractionation followed by in-gel trypsin digestion and in-solution digestion followed by strong cationic exchange (SCX) chromatography fractionation. Fractions were analyzed by LC-MS/MS using LTQ-Orbitrap Velos ETD mass spectrometer.

Peptides were identified using database dependent searches against the nonredundant (nr) protein database of Leishmania major strain Fredlin (n=8412; TriTrypDB version 4.1) submitted to Mascot (version 2.2) and Sequest search engines using Proteome Discoverer (Thermo Scientific, version 1.2).

N-terminal acetylated peptides were determined by searching mass spectrometry data using N-terminal acetylation as a modification during database searches.

datasetPresenter.name: tconIL3000_quantitativeMassSpec_Eyford_iTRAQ_RSRC
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Tc PCF EPI MET BSF QProt
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomes of the three main insect stages and bloodstream form T. congolense IL3000 were determined by quatitative ITRAQ analyses.
datasetPresenter.description: Proteins purified from Trypanosoma congolense IL3000 life cycle stages (bloodstream form, cultured procyclic form, epimastigote, and metcyclic form) were labeled using different isobaric tags (ITRAQ). A pooled peptide sample was analyzed by LC-S/MS, protein assignments were made using ProteinPilot V2.0.1, and the iTRAQ data were analyzed to determine ratios of protein expression between life cycle stages.

datasetPresenter.name: tgraANR4_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma grayi ANR4 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Sequence and annotation of the Trypanosoma grayi ANR4 genome.

Sequencing and assembly:
Genomic DNA from Trypanosoma grayi ANR4 (Wendy Gibson, University of Bristol) was extracted from agarose plugs using standard phenol/chloroform methods. DNA was sequenced by 91 bp paired-end Illumina sequencing at the Beijing Genomics Institute. Reads were clipped based on phred score >20 using the fastx program. Read errors and ambiguous bases were then corrected using the ALLPATHS find read errors algorithm. Duplicate reads and reads with a post-clipped length of less than 20 nucleotides were discarded using custom Perl scripts.

The clipped, corrected and filtered reads were then assembled using Velvet and multiple kmer sizes (kmer = 31, 41, 51 and 61). The resulting contigs from all assemblies were then post-assembled using CAP3 to yield a final genome assembly. The estimated genome size is 29,355,514 bases, approximately 48x coverage.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruSylvioX10-1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma cruzi Sylvio X10/1 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
This assembly of Trypanosoma cruzi Sylvio X10/1 was assembled from 210 X PacBio sequence data and a previous Illumina data set. the core regions of these scaffolds were aligned against the core regions of the TcVI CL Brener reference genome using ABACAS (http://abacas.sourceforge.net), producing 47 pseudomolecules. The genome sequence was annotated using a new kinetoplastid genome annotation pipeline combining homology-based gene model transfer with de novo gene prediction. To allow for the sensitive identification of partial genes, input sequences were split at stretches of undefined bases, effectively creating a set of 'pseudocontigs', each of which does not contain any gaps. Gene finding was then performed on both the original sequences and the pseudocontigs using AUGUSTUS, which also calls partial genes at the boundaries of each pseudocontig. AUGUSTUS models were trained on 800 genes randomly sampled from the 41 Esmeraldo-type T. cruzi CL Brener chromosomes in GeneDB

The data set represents the Sylvio X10/1 genome that was reassembled and reannotated in 2017. The original version of the genome and annotation, unchanged from the Genbank record, is also loaded into TriTrypDB:

Trypanosoma cruzi Sylvio X10/1-2012

datasetPresenter.name: tcruSylvioX10-1-2012_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma cruzi Sylvio X10/1-2012 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Trypanosoma cruzi Sylvio X10 was sequenced to 30X coverage using 454 and Illumina HiSeq technologies. The Illumina and 454 reads were assembled separately and subsequently merged to produce 38 Mb genome in 27,019 contigs with an N50 of 2307. EuPathDB downloaded the data from GenBank.

This data represents the 2012 version of the genome and annotation. TriTrypDB also integrated an updated version of this genome and annotation directly from the Andersson lab. This genome record is:

Trypanosoma cruzi Sylvio X10/1

Secreted proteins, precipitated from media after incubating with L. braziliensis IOC-L 2463 promastigotes, were resuspended and analyzed by 2DE, LC-MS/MS. Peptide discovery was performed against NCBI nonredundant database (V 050623).

datasetPresenter.name: ltarParrotTarII_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leishmania tarentolae Parrot-TarII Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The genome sequence of Leishmania tarentolae Parrot-TarII, a kinetoplastid parasite that is non-pathogenic to humans, was resolved to an average 16-fold coverage using GS-FLX, Roche 454 and Illumina technologies. After de novo assembly, sequences of specific chromosomes were built using contigs and scaffolds based on their homology to L. major. Gene identification was performed by comparing the assembled L. tarentolae genome sequence to the putative genes of L. infantum, L. major and L. braziliensis using BLAST 2.2.21.

datasetPresenter.name: ldonBPK282A1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leishmania donovani BPK282A1 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Leishmania donovani BPK282A1 is a Nepalese strain isolated from a patient with visceral leishmaniasis. EuPathDB downloaded the genome sequence and annotation from GenBank.

Leishmania donovani BPK282A1 genome was sequenced by combining single and paired-end reads from the 454 GS FLX Titanium platform (median 22-fold coverage) with reads from Illumina Genome Analyzer (median 52-fold coverage). The 454 data were assembled de novo, and the Illumina data were used to iteratively correct errors in the consensus sequence and close gaps. The initial set of contigs—50% of which were 44.4 kb or greater (N50)—were aligned, ordered, and oriented against the L. infantum JPCM5 reference genome to produce an assembled high quality draft L. donovani genome of length 32.4 Mb containing 2154 contigs and with a final N50 of 45.5 kb. The genome was annotated by identifying orthologous genes within the L. infantum genome and transferring their annotation onto the L. donovani draft assembly.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: This genome is being actively curated at GeneDB. User comments added to this gene will be reviewed and incorporated into the official annotation if appropriate.

datasetPresenter.name: tevaSTIB805_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: T. evansi STIB 805 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Genomic DNA was isolated from T. (b.) evansi STIB805 (a strain isolated by Zhao-Rong Lun in 1985 from a water buffalo in Jiangsu province, eastern China) and sequenced by 454 and Illumina technology. Mega-chromosome sequences were assembled using genome reference strain T. b. brucei TREU (Trypanosomiasis Research Edinburgh University) 927 v4 as template and CLC Genomics software. Annotation of the T. (b.) evansi genome was performed using a combination of RATT (Rapid Annotation Transfer Tool, Otto et al. (2011) Nucleic Acids Res. 39: e57) and AutoMagi (Aggarwal et al. (2003) BMC Bioinformatics 4: 23), followed by manual curation. SNPs and InDels were identified using CLC Genomics software.

DNA source: Dr Zhao-Rong-Lun, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou

Sequencing: Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou; Pathogen Sequencing Unit, Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute

Sequence assembly and SNP/InDel calling: Dr Achim Schnaufer, University of Edinburgh

Genome annotation: Dr Jason Carnes and Atashi Anupama, Seattle BioMed

Manual curation: Dr Jason Carnes and Atashi Anupama, Seattle BioMed; Dr Achim Schnaufer, University of Edinburgh

The work was supported by NIH grant R01AI69057 and MRC grant G0600129 to AS, NIH grant AI014102 to KS and a Praemium Academiae award to JL.

It is requested that users of this T. (b.) evansi sequence assembly acknowledge the Principal Investigators and Collaborators listed below. Any publications that propose to use whole genome or chromosome data should contact Achim Schnaufer (achim.schnaufer@ed.ac.uk), Ken Stuart (ken.stuart@seattlebiomed.org) and Julius Lukeš ((jula@paru.cas.cz) for the use of pre-publication data.

datasetPresenter.name: tcrumarinkelleiB7_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma cruzi marinkellei Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Trypanosoma cruzi marinkellei is a bat-associated parasite of the subgenus Schizotrypanum and it is regarded as a T. cruzi subspecies. The genome was sequenced to 30X coverage using 454 and Illumina HiSeq technologies. The Illumina and 454 reads were assembled separately and subsequently merged to produce 34 Mb genome in 23,154 contigs with an N50 of 2846. EuPathDB downloaded the data from GenBank.

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_massSpec_Tsigankov_Pro_Ama_PhosphoProteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Phosphoproteomic analysis of L. donovani 1SR amastigotes and promastigotes mapped to L. infantum JPCM5.
datasetPresenter.description:
Phosphoproteomic analysis of L. donovani 1SR amastigotes and promastigotes
Three independent cultures of axenic promastigotes and amastigotes were harvested at midlog phase, their proteins extracted, treated with trypsin, subjected to a TiO2 column for phosphopeptide enrichment, and finally analyzed by QStar pulsar I Q-TOF.

Peptide annotation using the L. infantum proteome revealed 1614 phosphorylated amino acid residues that represent 627 distinct L. infantum proteins. Manual analysis of all MS spectra was carried out to validate all phosphorylation sites.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Price_Flagellar_Proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Total Flagellar Proteome from bloodstream form
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparative proteomics identifying interactive partners of Deflagellation Inducible Protein 13 (DIP13)
datasetPresenter.description: We employed the proteomic non-gel technique isobaric tag for relative and absolute quantitation (iTRAQ) to identify and compare the relative amounts of flagellar proteins in T. brucei bloodstream form parasites over-expressing T. brucei Deflagellation Inducible Protein 13 (TbDIP13) compared to the parental line. A total of 257 proteins were identified, representing the first flagellar proteome of T. brucei BSF cells. No novel proteins were identified in the DIP13 overexpressing cell extracts compared to the parental line. The data set was filtered to exclude proteins with a pI of 10.2 or greater as these are likely to be ribosomal contaminants. The remaining data set contains 184 proteins, of which 121 have previously been found in the T. brucei PCF flagellar proteome.

datasetPresenter.name: _massSpec_Marchini_phosphoproteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Phsophoproteome of the T. cruzi differentiation process from non-infective epimastigotes to infective metacyclic trypomastigotes.
datasetPresenter.description: The phosphoproteome during metacyclogenesis was determined by analyzing five T. cruzi Dm28c time points during the differentiation process: epimastigotes, 30 min stressed cells, 2 hr stressed cells, 12 hr stressed cells, and metacyclic trypomastigotes. Peptide digests from each time point were enriched for phosphopeptides using TiO2 chromatography and analyzed by NanoLC-MS/MS. Proteins were identified using Mascot and MaxQuant.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Urbaniak_BSF_Unenriched_And_Kinobead_Enriche_Proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparison of total proteome to the kinase-enriched proteome in T. brucei 427
datasetPresenter.description: Whole cell lysates of bloodstream form Trypanosoma brucei 427 MITat1.4 were solubilised with 0.8% NP-40, centrifuged at 145,000 x g for 1 h and the supernatant enriched using kinobeads (mixed immobilised ATP-mimic kinase inhibitors) prior to reductive alkylation, tryptic digest, and analysis by LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: _quantitativeMassSpec_Marchini_Metacyclogenesis_Proteomics_
datasetPresenter.shortAttribution: de Godoy and Marchini et al.
datasetPresenter.summary: Quantitative proteomic study of T. cruzi (Dm28c) metacyclogenesis
datasetPresenter.description:
Differentially expressed proteins involved in T. cruzi Dm28c metacyclogenesis determined by quantitative proteomics.

Experimental Design:
The process of epimastigote differentiation into metacyclic trypomastigotes was approximated by collecting six distinct developmental stages. Five technical replicates were run for each time point, and the experiment was repeated in the same way for two biological replicates, resulting in a total of ten samples for each of the differentiation stages.

Samples:
1. Epi - untreated epimastigotes
2. St30m - epimastigotes after nutritional stress for 30 minutes:
3. St2h - epimastigotes after nuritional stress for 2 hours:
4. Ad12h - epimastigotes - adhered for 12 hours:
5. InitMeta - initial stages of metacyclogenesis
6. Meta - metacyclic trypomastigotes harvested after 96 hr incubation

Sample Preparation:
Samples were lysed for protein extraction, digested in-solution with trypsin, and analyzed by LC-MS/MS on the LTQ-Orbitrap.

Proteomic analysis:
Identification and quantification of peptides were performed with the MaxQuant software package. Proteins were searched against a "decoy database" prepared by reversing the sequence of each entry of the T. cruzi protein sequence database (containing 19 615 protein sequences, downloaded in August 30, 2007 from GeneDB. Protein quantification was performed using a label-free approach, where peptides eluting from each LC run are detected as three-dimensional features - retention time versus signal intensity (extracted ion chromatogram, XIC) versus mass/charge - aligned and compared across runs.

Proteomic analysis of SUMOylation targets in T. cruzi CL Brener epimastigotes.
SUMOylation enriched protein samples were prepared by affinity chromatography from a T. cruzi CL Brener epimastigote cell line expressing TcSUMO (test) or from wild type cells (mock). datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Urbaniak_CompProt_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Comparative proteomics of bloodstream and procyclic forms (T.b. 427)
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparison of T. brucei 427 procyclic and bloodstream form trypanosomes via SILAC proteomic analysis.
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomic analysis comparing T. brucei 427 procyclic and bloodstream forms.
Procyclic form Trypanosoma brucei clone 29.13.6 cells were grown in modified SDM-79 medium containing L-Arginine.HCl U-13C6 and L-Lysine.2HCl U-13C6 (heavy label). Bloodstream form Trypanosoma brucei 427 MITat1.2 were grown in HMI-9T. Cells were hypotonically lysed at 5 × 109 cells/mL, equal cell numbers mixed, and the combined suspension solubilized in 4% SDS at 95°C prior to washing with 8 M urea and reductive alkylation. Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE prior to in-gel tryptic digest, or treated with trypsin in solution and the peptides fractionated by strong cation exchange prior to analysis by LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_quantitativeMassSpec_Urbaniak_CompProt_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Comparative proteomics of bloodstream and procyclic forms - Quantitative (T.b. 427)
datasetPresenter.summary: Quantitative Comparison of T. brucei 427 procyclic and bloodstream form trypanosomes via SILAC proteomic analysis.
datasetPresenter.description:
Quantitative proteomic analysis comparing T. brucei 427 procyclic and bloodstream forms.
Procyclic form Trypanosoma brucei clone 29.13.6 cells were grown in modified SDM-79 medium containing L-Arginine.HCl U-13C6 and L-Lysine.2HCl U-13C6 (heavy label) and bloodstream form Trypanosoma brucei 427 MITat1.2 were grown in HMI-9T. Cells were hypotonically lysed at 5 × 109 cells/mL, equal cell numbers mixed, and the combined suspension solubilized in 4% SDS at 95°C prior to washing with 8 M urea and reductive alkylation. Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE prior to in-gel tryptic digest, or treated with trypsin in solution and the peptides fractionated by strong cation exchange prior to analysis by LC-MS/MS. Data are presented as Log2 Fold-change Pcf/Bsf with a 1% false discovery rate; where no ratio is reported, one could not be accurately determined.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_quantitativeMassSpec_BSF_PCF_Surface_Proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: T. brucei proteomics of the cell surface from both PCF and BSF stages
datasetPresenter.description:
This study utilized surface biotinylation, coupled with affinity purification and shotgun proteomics, to obtain cell surface proteomes from procyclic (PCF) (insect midgut) and bloodstream-form (BSF) T. brucei. Comparison of surface proteomes from procyclic and bloodstream forms reveals extensive stage-specific surface protein remodeling that includes individual paralogues within protein families. In this study, endogenous GPI-specific phospholipase C (GPI-PLC) activity was used to release VSG from the cell surface prior to streptavidin purification of surface proteins.
Surface-biotinylated cells were fractionated into Lysate (L), Insoluble (I), Soluble (S), Unbound (U), and Bound (B) fractions

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Hill_Flagellum_Surface_And_Matrix_Proteomes_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Bloodstream form Flagellum Surface and Matrix Proteomes
datasetPresenter.summary: Flagellum surface and matrix proteomes from T. brucei bloodstream form trypanosomes.
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomic analysis of flagellum surface and matrix from T. brucei bloodstream form trypanosomes.
Lateral flagellar connections to the T. brucei bloodstream form cell body were removed by tetracycline induced RNAi against fla1. Whole cells were surface biotinylated and intact, membrane enclosed flagella were isolated by shearing. Soluble, surface flagellar proteins were separated from matrix proteins by streptavidin affinity chromatography. MudPIT analysis revealed 158 surface proteins and 666 matrix proteins.

The transcriptomes of L. mexicana axenic amastigotes and promastigotes as well as amastigotes derived from infected mouse macrophage were determined by mRNA sequencing using paired-end Illumina protocols.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Archer_Stuart_CellCycle_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Gene expression profiling of the T. brucei cell cycle by RNA-sequencing.
datasetPresenter.description:
Time course analysis of the Trypanosoma brucei transcriptome during the cell cycle.
Analysis of gene expression over the Trypanosoma brucei cell cycle was performed by measuring changes in mRNA abundance on a transcriptome-wide scale. A Double-Cut Elutriation (DCE) procedure was developed to select unperturbed, highly synchronous cell populations from log-phase cultures, and this was compared with synchronization by starvation.

Cell populations were isolated from four time-points post-selection: early (0.5 hours) and late (3 hours) G1 phase, S-phase (5.5 hours), and G2 phase (7.25 hours), each population consisting almost entirely of the desired cell cycle stage. Poly-A+ RNA from these cells was selected and subjected to expression profiling by RNA-seq. Between 13 and 17 million high-quality reads per time-point could be mapped to the T. brucei genome.

templateInjector.prop: Cell Cycle Stages: Early G1 (0.5 hrs), Late G1 (3 hrs), S (5.5 hrs) and G2 (7.25 hrs)

datasetPresenter.name: lmajFriedlin_HTS_SNP_Mottram_Multiple_HTS_SNPs_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genomic sequence reads - strains Friedlin and LV39
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole genome resequencing data from Leishmania major strains Friedlin and LV39 were used to call SNPs and determine CNV at the gene and chromosome level.
datasetPresenter.description:
Whole genome resequencing data from Leishmania major strains Friedlin and LV39 were analyzed for single nucleotide polymorphisms and copy number variation using L. major Friedlin as a reference.

SNP analysis
Reads are aligned to the reference genome using Bowtie 2 and realigned around indels using GATK. SNPs, indels and concensus sequence are generated with VARSCAN and stored in the database.

CNV analysis
The median read depth is set to the organism's ploidy and each chromosome's median read depth is normalized to this value. Contigs that are not assigned to chromosome are excluded from this analysis. Gene copy number is similarly calculated using a normalized read depth for each gene. To compare the number of genes in the resequenced genome to the reference genome, genes are grouped into clusters that are inferred to have originated by tandem duplication.

datasetPresenter.name: lbraMHOMBR75M2904_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leishmania braziliensis M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) sequence and annotation from GeneDB.
datasetPresenter.description:
This resource includes chromosome sequences and annotations for Leishmania braziliensis. Sequence data for Leishmania braziliensis M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) were downloaded from GeneDB (sequence and annotated features).


L. (Viannia) braziliensis M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) is a reference strain from Evandro Chagas Institute, Belém, Brazil. This strain was isolated by direct culture from a lesion on the right side of the thorax of a man who had been performing survey work in Serra dos Carajás, Brazilian Amazonia.


The LB2904 clone is infective in hamsters and BALB/c mice and can be genetically transfected and cloned on plates.


Sequencing of L. braziliensis was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: This genome is being actively curated at GeneDB. User comments added to this gene will be reviewed and incorporated into the official annotation if appropriate.

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Leishmania infantum JPCM5 (MCAN/ES/98/LLM-724)
datasetPresenter.description:
L. infantum JPCM5 strain (MCAN/ES/98/LLM-724) first isolated in Madrid (Spain) from a naturally infected dog that developed VL, and it showed high virulence in laboratory dog infections. This strain was cryopreserved at the Centro Nacional de Microbiología (Instituto de Salud Carlos III, Madrid, Spain) and distributed to different laboratories around the world. The genome was sequenced using Pacific Biosciences (PacBio) technology, used to produce sequencing reads of 10–15 kb in lengths, and Illumina technology to generate paired-end short-reads.
This genome is being actively curated at Leish-ESP. User comments will be reviewed and incorporated into the official annotation if appropriate.

Sequencing of L. major was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit, Seattle Biomedical Research Institute and The European Leishmania major Friedlin Genome Sequencing Consortium.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruCLBrenerNon-Esmeraldo-like_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for the non-Esmeraldo haplotype of Trypanosoma cruzi CL Brener.
datasetPresenter.description:
The nuclear genome of Trypanosoma cruzi CL Brener is being sequenced by the TIGR-Seattle Biomedical Research Institute-Karolinska Institute T. cruzi Sequencing Consortium (TSK-TSC). Funding for this project is being provided by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID). he T. cruzi CL Brener genome was assembled using all available sequence information. The result is a genome of 41 chromosome pairs ranging in size from 78 kb to 2.4 Mb. The non-Esmeraldo-like haplotype are the "P" features and the Esmeraldo-like haplotype are the "S" features.

The 23,216 gene models were initially annotated through a system that executes multiple steps of homology search and then determines the best call based on multiple sources of evidence. In a next step, a more refined gene function prediction was implemented by a combination of manual curation of T. cruzi specific genes as well as transfer of manual curation of gene products from their T. brucei or L. major orthologs.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: This genome is being actively curated at GeneDB. User comments added to this gene will be reviewed and incorporated into the official annotation if appropriate.

Mapping of gene coordinates from contigs to chromosomes for T. cruzi was generated by Rick Tarleton's group at the University of Georgia, Athens, Georgia.
