datasetPresenter.name: lmajSD75.1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Leishmania major SD 75.1
datasetPresenter.description:
Leishmania major strain SD 75.1 genome from WUSTL.

The Leishmania major (MHOM/SN/74/SD) was obtained from David Sacks (NIH). The properties of this line are described in here. A clonal derivative (75.1) was prepared by Deborah E. Dobson (Washington University School of Medicine) and used for sequencing.

Genomic DNA was made by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to minimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA; this was prepared by Natalia Akopyants (Washington University School of Medicine).

Next-generation sequences on the 454 instruments were produced for a draft assembly. Total sequence coverage of 454 instrument reads was ~31X (Fragments 19X, 3Kb PE 9X, 8Kb PE 3X) using a genome size estimate of 40Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the Newbler software (Roche 454). This first draft assembly was referred to as L_major_SD_1.0. This version has been cleaned of contaminants. The assembly is made up of a total of 1904 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 691kb (N50 contig length for the 4009 contigs was 27kb). The assembly spans 30.8Mb.

This work was supported by NIH grants AI29646 and AI 31078 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Institute at Washington University.

For questions regarding this L_major_SD_1.0 assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@watson.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Leishmania major (strain/isolate SD 75.1) genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).

DNA source - Drs. Stephen M. Beverley & Natalia Akopyants, Department of Molecular Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequencing - The Genome Institute, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequence assembly – The Genome Institute, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Annotation: This genome was annotated using an annotation pipeline tailored to the kinteoplastids. The pipeline was developed by the Parasite Genomics team at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute and a publication on the subject is expected soon.

Citation upon use of this assembly in a manuscript:
It is requested that users of this Leishmania major (strain/isolate SD 75.1) sequence assembly acknowledge Stephen M. Beverley and The Genome Institute, Washington University School of Medicine in any publications that result from use of this sequence assembly. Any publications that propose to use whole genome or chromosome data should contact The Genome Institute at Washington University (gweinsto@wustl.edu or wwarren@wustl.edu) for the use of pre-publication data. Please refer to the Genome Center Data Use Policy for further information regarding proper use of data and proper citation.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: Please consult with the Principal Investigator before undertaking large scale analyses of this unpublished sequence or annotation.

datasetPresenter.name: lmajFriedlin_massSpec_exosomeBasedSecretion_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomic analysis of exosomes secreted by L. donovani under early-infection-like conditions
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomic analysis of exosomes secreted by L. donovani under early-infection-like conditions
Exosomes were purified from L. donovani Sudan S2 promasatigote conditioned medium. Exosome pellets were soubilized, trypsinized and analyzed by LC-MS/MS. Fragment spectra were searched against the L. major (May 2006 compilation, 17392 sequences) protein database using Mascot (v2.2, Matrix Science).

datasetPresenter.name: _massSpec_Brent_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomic analysis of five T. cruzi Brazil life cycle stages (amastigote, epimastigote, metacyclic trypomastigote, trypomastigote).
datasetPresenter.description: Metacyclic trypomastigotes, amastigotes, trypomastigotes, and epimastigotes of T. cruzi Brazil were isolated and proteins were extracted from whole-cell or subcellular lysates. Digested peptides from protein preparations were analyzed by offline LC, and online LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_massSpec_Zilberstein_PTM_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomes of post-translationally modified proteins (glycosylated, acetylated, methylated and phosphorylated) from L. infantum promastigotes, amastigotes and differentiating promastigotes.
datasetPresenter.description: Proteomic analysis of post-translationally modified proteins (glycosylated, acetylated, methylated and phosphorylated) from L. infantum promastigotes, amastigotes and differentiating promastigotes. Cellular proteins were extracted from axenic promastigotes, amastigotes, and differentiating parasites and analyzed by iTRAQ analysis. The identified peptides were analyzed to detect post-translationally modified amino acids. Peptide spectra were screened against the L. infantum V3.0 genome from GeneDB.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Procyclic_Form_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome of T. brucei TREU927 procyclic form mitochondrial enriched fraction.
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomic analysis of a T. brucei TREU927 procyclic form mitochondrial enriched fraction.
A mitochondria enriched protein fraction was prepared from Trypanosoma brucei TREU927 procyclic form cells Detergent soluble fractions were trypsin digested and the resulting peptides were analyzed by 2D-LC-MS/MS. Insoluble fractions were dissolved in 1X SDS-PAGE buffer and analyzed by 1D-LC-MS/MS. The mass spectrometry data was analyzed against T. brucei sequence databases using SEQUEST.

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_massSpec_Brotherton_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Stage-specific expression of basic proteins in L. infantum.
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomic analysis of basic proteins from promastigotes and amastigotes.
L. infantum (MHOM/MA/67/ITMAP-263) promastigotes and amastigotes were purified and whole cell lysates were fractionated by free-flow electrophoresis using conditions that enhance detection of basic proteins. Fractions from FFE were pooled and analyzed by 1DE- or 2DE- LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_microarrayExpression_Myler_promastigote_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Microarray time course of axenic promastigote-to-amastigote differentiation in Leishmania donovani 1SR
datasetPresenter.description:
Axenic promastigote-to-amastigote differentiation of Leishmania donovani 1SR.
Late log phase promastigotes were subjected to a differentiation signal (medium, temperature and CO2 changes), and total RNA was extracted from cells at 0, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 15, 24, and 120 h after exposure to differentiation signal. cDNA synthesis, Cy3 labeling and hybridization to Nimblegene arrays were performed at Nimblegen. Data are aligned to the L. infantum JPCM5 reference genome.

Sample harvest times were chosen to correlate with the 4 morphology-based phases of axenic L. donovani differentiation:
Phase I (0-5 h) -signal perception with no morphological change,
Phase II (5-10 h) -movement cessation and aggregation,
Phase III (10-25 h) -morphological transformation to amastigote-shape cells,
Phase IV (25-120 h) -amastigote maturation.

templateInjector.prop: percentile - Linfantum promastigote time-course - biorep01;percentile - Linfantum promastigote time-course - biorep02;Linfantum promastigote time-course

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_massSpec_OuelletteM_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomic analysis of L. infantum metacyclic stage (pH5-6).
datasetPresenter.description: Evidence of protein expression in L. infantum metacyclic stage. Proteins were analyzed on 2D gel followed by free-flow electrophoresis and Mass Spec analysis.

datasetPresenter.name: _massSpec_Queiroz_Epimastigote_Cell_Surface_Proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome from epimastigote cell surface isolated by trypsin or biotinylation and analyzed by LC-MS/MS.
datasetPresenter.description:
Epimastigote cell surface proteome of Trypanosoma cruzi Berenice.

Cell surface proteins were isolated by an optimized trypsin protocol (SHAVE) or by biotinylation/streptavidin affinity chromotography protocol. SHAVE and biotinylated protein samples were digested with trypsin and the resulting peptides were analyzed by LC-MS/MS.

Mass spec data were viewed in Xcaliber v.2.1 and processed with Proteome Discoverer v.1.3 beta. The raw files were searched with Mascot v.2.3 against a Trypanosoma cruzi database downloaded via Database on Demand that contained proteins found in UniProt/SWISS-PROT and UniProt/TrEMBL.

datasetPresenter.name: _massSpec_Proteomics_Membrane_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Membrane Proteins from insect developmental forms (strain G)
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomic Analysis of Detergent-Solubilized Membrane Proteins from Insect-Developmental Forms of T. cruzi.
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomic Analysis of Detergent-Solubilized Membrane Proteins from Insect-Developmental Forms of T. cruzi. Data was provided by Igor C. Almeida, Department of Biological Sciences, The Border Biomedical Research Center, University of Texas at El Paso, and Jose Franco da Silveira, Departamento de Microbiologia, Imunologia e Parasitologia, Escola Paulista de Medicina, UNIFESP.

Epimastigotes and metacyclic trypomastigotes of T. cruzi strain G were isolated and used to prepare GPI-anchored membrane protein-enriched samples. Protein samples were analyzed by 2DLC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruCLBrenerEsmeraldo-like_massSpec_Reservosomes_SubCellular_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomic analysis of the reservosome, a subcellular organelle and the endpoint of the endocytic pathway in Trypanosoma cruzi epimastigotes.
datasetPresenter.description: Reservosomes were isolated from T. cruzi Dm28c epimastigotes and a membrane fraction was prepared from a portion of the purified organelles. Total protein from intact reservosomes or membrane fractions were analyzed by LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: lmajFriedlin_chipChipExper_Peter_Myler_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: TBP, TRF4, SNAp50, H3 binding by ChIP-chip
datasetPresenter.summary: Leishmania major chromosomal binding locations of TATA-binding protein (TBP or TRF4), Small Nuclear Activating Protein complex (SNAP50), and H3 histones determined using microarrays hybridized with DNA obtained through chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP-chip).
datasetPresenter.description: The chromosomal location of TATA-binding protein (TBP or TRF4), Small Nuclear Activating Protein complex (SNAP50), and H3 histones were assessed in Leishmania major using microarrays hybridized with DNA obtained through chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP-chip). The TBP and SNAP50 binding patterns were almost identical and high intensity peaks were associated with tRNAs and snRNAs. Only 184 peaks of acetylated H3 histone were found in the entire genome, with substantially higher intensity in rapidly-dividing cells than stationary-phase. The majority of the acetylated H3 peaks were found at divergent strand-switch regions, but some occurred at chromosome ends and within polycistronic gene clusters. Almost all these peaks were associated with lower intensity peaks of TBP/SNAP50 binding a few kilobases upstream, evidence that they represent transcription initiation sites.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Maree_NuclPosition_BF_PF_chipSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Nucleosome positions in Tb427 bloodstream and procyclic forms
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome-wide nucleosome positions in T. brucei Lister 427 bloodstream form and procyclic form using MNase-seq.
datasetPresenter.description: Genome-wide nucleosome positions were determined in T. brucei Lister 427 bloodstream and procyclic form parasites. Two bloodstream form cell lines (HNI_VO2, RYT3) and two procyclic form cell lines (Amsterdam WT, 221BsrDsRed) were analyzed using the same techniques. Chromatin from permeabilized cells was treated with MNAse to release the ~147 bp fragments bound to the nucleosome. Gel-purified 147 bp fragments were sequenced using 50nt Illumina paired-end sequencing.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Wedel-polIIandhistone_chipSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: RNA pol II, H2A.Z and H3 genome-wide distribution
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome-wide distribution of RNA pol II, H2A.Z and H3 based on ChIP-seq against endogenously tagged RPB9 (RNA pol II subunit), MNase-ChIP-seq using a custom-made antibodies against H2A.Z and H3.
datasetPresenter.description:
RNA pol II ChIP-seq:
The genome-wide distribution of RNA pol II enrichment by ChIP-seq was determined using a T. brucei Lister 427 cell line expressing Ty1-tagged RPB9, a subunit only found in the RNA pol II complex.

Cell culture:
Genetically modified Trypanosoma brucei strains were derived from the Lister 427 bloodstream-form MITat 1.2 (clone 221) derivative single marker cell line (SM) expressing T7 RNA polymerase and the Tet repressor and cultured at 37℃ in HMI-11 medium

Immunoprecipitation and Sequencing:
The RNA pol II ChIP was performed in cell lines, in which both alleles of RPB9, a subunit of the RNA pol II complex, contained an endogenous Ty1 tag. Except for minor changes, the ChIP was performed as described previously (Wedel & Siegel, 2017). Chromatin was fragmented by sonication and immunoprecipitation of DNA bound by RBP9 was performed using Dynabeads® Protein G (Invitrogen) coupled to a BB2 antibody (Bastin et al, 1996) at 4℃ overnight and under the presence of 300 mM NaCl. Bound material was washed, cross-links were reversed, and immunoprecipitated DNA was purified. Sequencing libraries were constructed and sequenced using an Illumina® NextSeq 500.

H2A.Z and H3 MNAse-seq:
Cell Culture:
Trypanosoma brucei wild-type cells were derived from Lister 427 bloodstream-form MITat 1.2 (clone 221) and cultured at 37℃ in HMI-11 medium.

Immunoprecipitation and Sequencing:
The genome-wide distribution of histone H3 and the histone variant H2A.Z was determined by MNase-ChIP-seq as described previously (Wedel & Siegel, 2017). To avoid over-digestion, we titrated MNase digestion such that a small population of dinucleosomal DNA remained. Next, nucleosomes were immunoprecipitated using a custom-made polyclonal H2A.Z antibody (Wedel & Siegel et al, 2017) or a custom-made histone H3 antiserum (Gassen et al, 2012), and the DNA was isolated and sequenced.

Sequencing of small 5'-triphosphate-containing RNA (transcription start sites):
Small RNA (<200nt) was purified from 5 x 10^7 cells. 2ug small RNA was treated with 1 unit of Terminator 5'-Phosphate-Dependent Exonuclease (TEX, Epicentre) for 30 min at 42 C to remove 5'-monophosphate RNA. The RNA was purified. Half was treated with 20 units RNA 5'-polyphosphatase to convert 5'-triphosphate RNA to 5'-monophosphate RNA. The other half was left untreated as a control. Sequencing libraries were constructed using NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina (New England BioLabs) and sequenced on and Illumina NextSeq 500. After alignment, a normalised ratios of coverage in treated and control samples were generated using the ratio subcommand from COVERnant.

link.text: RNA Pol II RPB9 ChIP-seq Trypanosoma brucei (SRA record)
View this Data Set in the Genome Browser

datasetPresenter.name: lmajFriedlin_Garcia-Silva_KKT1_Centromeres_chipSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled to high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-Seq) of L. major KKT1 (LmKKT1) clearly identified one major peak per chromosome.
datasetPresenter.description: Leishmania centromeres could not be identified by classical methods including telomere-associated chromosome fragmentation, and position mapping of topoisomerase II binding sites via etoposide-mediated cleavage. Hints for the centromere quest in Leishmania appeared recently with the description of unconventional kinetoplastid kinetochore proteins (KKT) in T. brucei (Akiyoshi and Gull Cell 2015). Chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled to high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-Seq) of L. major KKT1 (LmKKT1) clearly identified one major peak per chromosome. Each peak covers a region of 4 ±2 kb in size. No specific sequence feature could be found, but two grossly conserved motifs were found for 14/36 chromosomes; and a higher density of retroposon was observed in 27/36 centromeres. The identification of centromeres and of a kinetochore component of Leishmania chromosomes provide a tool to further study the composition of this unusual complex this may result in a better understanding of the molecular events leading to chromosomal segregation in this parasite and shed light on the hypothesis that 'permissive' segregation plays a role in mosaic aneuploidy.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_George_Cross_Splice_Leader_rnaSeqSplicedLeaderAndPolyASites_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Spliced Leader and Poly A Sites from bloodstream and procyclic forms
datasetPresenter.summary: Curated spliced leader and Polyadenylation for bloodstream and procyclic form Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427
datasetPresenter.description:
Curated Spliced Leader Sites
Illumina RNA sequencing data from bloodstream and procyclic Lister 427 and procyclic TREU 927 were used to identify spliced leader and polyadenylation sites. Data were put through several filters prior to final manual curation. Tags that met the following criterion were retained:
1. contained the last 14 contiguous nucleotides of the spliced leader,
2. were > 13 nt long after removing all of the spliced leader sequence and adding "AG" to the 5-prime end,
3. gave unique and perfect matches (32 or 36 bp sequences: 2 mismatches were allowed for 76-bp sequences) on the correct strand, with at least 2 hits per splice-acceptor sites (SAS).
Data for 6,959 genes (10,857 SAS) met these criteria. Data from bloodstream and procyclic forms were merged.

Curated Polyadenylation sites
Sequences that started with at least eight consecutive Ts were identified and sequences greater than 15 nt long were aligned by BLAT against the T. brucei genome. The BLAT output was manually curated by deleting records:
1. where the number of hits per tag was >14,
2. with predicted UTR length >5000 nt,
3. that did not yield unique genome hits.

link.text: Detailed curated data, with independent values for bloodstream and procyclic forms available for download as an EXCEL file

templateInjector.prop: T. brucei curated splice site reads from George Cross

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_microarrayExpression_GSE17026_Matthews_Keith_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Life cycle stages and differentiation time course
datasetPresenter.summary: mRNA expression profiles of T. brucei AnTat1.1 slender and stumpy bloodstream stages, as well as 4 time points during the transition of the stumpy to the procyclic life-cycle stage.
datasetPresenter.description:
Life cycle stages and differentiation time course of Trypanosoma brucei AnTat1.1
Cells undergoing synchronous life cycle differentiation were analyzed by microarray. mRNA from six biological samples (5 biological replicates each) was converted to cDNA, labeled with dye and hybridized to JCVI Trypanosoma brucei V3 microarrays. Samples analyzed represent the slender and stumpy life cycle stages, as well as 4 time points during the transition from stumpy to procyclic life cycle stage.

1. Slender bloodstream form: harvested 3 days post-infection of cyclophosphamide treated mice
2. 0 h time point (Stumpy bloodstream form): harvested 6 days post-infection of cyclophosphamide treated mice
3. 1 h time point: harvested 1 hour after initiating differentiation with cis-aconitate
4. 6 h time point: harvested 6 hour after initiating differentiation with cis-aconitate
5. 18 h time point: harvested 18 hour after initiating differentiation with cis-aconitate
6. 48 h time point: harvested 48 hour after initiating differentiation with cis-aconitate

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_microarrayExpression_GSE18049_Parsons_Marilyn_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Expression profiling of five life cycle stages
datasetPresenter.summary: Gene expression profiling of five life cycle stages determined via microarray
datasetPresenter.description:
Gene expression profiling of five life cycle stages determined via microarray
Whole genome comparison of RNA levels for both protein coding genes and structural RNAs in five different life-cycle stages: cultured bloodstream, in vivo slender bloodstream, in vivo stumpy bloodstream, log-phase procyclic culture and stationary-phase procyclic culture forms. Purified RNA was sent to Nimblegen for cDNA synthesis using oligo-dT priming, labeling and hybridization to oligonucleotide arrays containing 8110 probe-sets corresponding to nuclear genes. Data is averaged from three biological replicates.

templateInjector.prop: Average value from three independent biological replicates from five different life cycle stages.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_microarrayExpression_GSE8734_Estevez_Antonio_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome of TbDRBD3 depleted (RNAi) procyclic T. brucei cells compared to uninduced cells using glass slide microarrays.
datasetPresenter.description:
Comparison of the procyclic transcriptome of T. brucei depleted of the RNA-binding protein TbDRBD3 to that of uninduced cells using glass slide microarrays.

RNAi was induced for 48 h and total RNA was obtained from either uninduced or TbDRBD3-depleted cells. cDNA was hybridized to genomic T. brucei microarray glass slides containing about 24 000 independent random genomic clones. Four hybridizations (two biological replicates with a dye swap each) were analyzed.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_microarrayExpression_Clayton_Christine_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Expression profiling of in vitro differentiation
datasetPresenter.summary: Gene Expression profiling during in vitro differentiation from cultured bloodstream forms to procyclic forms.
datasetPresenter.description:
T. brucei AnTat1.1 gene expression profiling during the in vitro differentiation from slender bloodstream to stumpy and procyclic forms.
Eight samples harvested during in vitro differentiation were analyzed. RNA isolated from each sample was converted to cDNA using random primers, labeled with dye and hybridized to the JCVI Trypanosom brucei version 3 microarray.

Samples include:
1. Bloodstream form at low density (2 x 105 cells/ml)- representing bloodstream slender form.
2. Bloodstream form at high density (2 x 106 cells/ml)- representing bloodstream stumpy form.
3. 0.5 hr time point - harvested 0.5 hr after inducing differentiation with cis-aconitate.
4. 1 hr time point - harvested 1 hr post-induction
5. 12 hr time point - harvested 12 hr post-induction.
6. 24 hr time point - harvested 24 hr post-induction.
7. 48 hr time point - harvested 48 hr post-induction.
8. 72 hr time point - harvested 72 hr post-induction.

templateInjector.prop: Time points in hours. High and low density blood forms (bf-hd and bf-ld) represent the 0 hour in the time series).

datasetPresenter.name: tcruCLBrenerEsmeraldo-like_microarrayExpression_Tarleton_Rick_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Microarray analysis of the T. cruzi Brazil trypomastigote, amastigote, epimastigotes and metacyclic life-cycle stages.
datasetPresenter.description:
T. cruzi life-cycle stage transcriptomes.

Transcriptomes of Trypanosoma cruzi Brazil major life cycle stages - trypomastigotes, amastigotes, epimastigotes, and metacyclic trypomastigotes, were determined by microarray. Total RNA from each life-cycle stage was converted to cDNA, labeled with dye and hybridized to whole genome microarrays. Each sample was co-hybridized with a reference cDNA sample comprised of a mixture of all 4 samples.

Six hybridizations were performed for each life-cycle stage. The hybridizations consisted of three dye-swap experiments from three independent samples (biological replicates). In each case, the experimental sample was from a single life-cycle stage and the control sample was an equal mixture of all four life-cycle stages. A total of 24 hybridizations were preformed.

link.text: Microarrays were obtained from the Pathogen Functional Genomics Resource Center

templateInjector.prop: Life Cycle Stages: trypomastigotes(TRP), amastigotes (AMA), epimastigotes (EPI), and metacyclic trypomastigotes (MET).

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_sageTag_DGETag_frequencies_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Frequencies of digital gene expression tags that were observed in studies using RNA from T. brucei gambiense.
datasetPresenter.description:
Frequencies of tags that were observed in studies using RNA from T. brucei gambiense.

The digital gene expression (DGE) tags represent a 21 bp tag usually from the first NlaIII restriction site upstream of the poly A tail on mRNA transcript. A detailed description of the method and experiment is available in Veitch et al ( Veitch NJ, Johnson PCD, Trivedi U, Terry S, Wildridge D and MacLeod A. Digital gene expression analysis of two life-cycle stages of the human-infective parasite, Trypanosoma brucei gambiense reveals differentially expressed clusters of co-regulated genes. BMC Genomics, 2010, 11:124-137). DGE tags were created from three procyclic-form and three bloodstream-form Trypanosoma brucei gambiense STIB386 in vitro cultures. The 21bp tags have been aligned to the T.b.brucei 927 and T.b.gambiense Dal genome databases, allowing for up to a 2 bp mismatch. Tags that only align once to the genome are represented, so tags that are not unique are not present. The differential expression of bloodstream-form versus procyclic-form T.b.gambiense DGE tags is available to view for each tag.

Publication is available from the PubMed http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20175885

Digital gene expression analysis of two life cycle stages of the human-infective parasite, Trypanosoma brucei gambiense reveals differentially expressed clusters of co-regulated genes. BMC Genomics. 2010 Feb 22;11:124.

datasetPresenter.name: cfasCfCl_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Crithidia fasciculata Cf-C1 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
The Crithidia fasciculata Cf-C1 was obtained from Dr. Larry Simpson, University of California, Los Angeles. Genomic DNA was prepared by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to rminimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA, and was provided by Drs. Natalia Akopyants, Lon-Fye Lye and Stephen Beverley, Washington University School of Medicine.

A combination of next-generation sequencing and Sanger reads were produced for a draft assembly. Total sequence coverage of 454 instrument reads was 26X (Fragments 10X, 3Kb PE 14X, 8Kb PE 2X) and Sanger reads was .75X using a genome size estimate of 40Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the CABOG software (Bioinformatics 24:2818-2824 2008). This first draft assembly was referred to as Crithidia_9.0. This version has been cleaned of contaminants and had some remaining vector trimmed from contigs. The assembly is made up of a total of 1043 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 122kb (N50 contig length for the 2847 contigs was 28kb). The assembly spans 34.5Gb.

This work was supported by NIH grant AI29646 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Institute at Washington University.

For questions regarding this Crithidia fasciculata assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@watson.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Crithidia fasciculata genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).

DNA source - Drs. Stephen Beverley, Natalia Akopyants, and Lon-Fye Lye, Department of Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequencing - The Genome Institute, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.



Sequence assembly (pseudochromosome and scaffolds) and annotation - Drs. Peter Myler and Gowthaman Ramasamy, Seattle Biomedical Research Institute, Seattle, WA. Annotation: This genome was annotated using an annotation pipeline tailored to the kinteoplastids. The pipeline was developed by the Parasite Genomics team at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute and a publication on the subject is expected soon.



It is requested that users of this Crithidia sequence assembly acknowledge Stephen M. Beverley and The Genome Institute, Washington University School of Medicine in any publications that result from use of this sequence assembly. Any publications that propose to use whole genome or chromosome data should contact The Genome Institute at Washington University (gweinsto@wustl.edu or wwarren@wustl.edu) for the use of pre-publication data. Please refer to the Genome Center Data Use Policy for further information regarding proper use of data and proper citation.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: NOTE. This is an unpublished draft genome assembly and annotation. Minor changes and corrections should be expected. A known issue exists with contig KB217557 which will be moved from chromosome 16 to 27 and contig KB217555 which will replace contig KB217557 on chromosome 16. Please consult with the Principal Investigators before undertaking large scale analyses of the annotation or underlying sequence.

datasetPresenter.summary: Expression profiles of axenic and intracellular amastigote forms of Leishmania infantum.
datasetPresenter.description:
Global mRNA expression profiling of Leishmania infantum MOHM/MA/67/ITMAP-263 axenic amastigotes compared to intracellular amastigotes.

RNA was extracted from promastigotes, axenic amastigotes and intracellular amastigotes. cDNA was generated from 5 micrograms of RNA using a random hexamer primer, labeled with dye and hybridized to a high density, multispecies 70-mer oligonucleotide array.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_RNAi_Horn_*rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: High-throughput phenotyping using RNAi target sequencing
datasetPresenter.summary: High Throughput Phenotyping in T. brucei bloodstream form using RNAi target sequencing.
datasetPresenter.description:
RNAi target sequencing coverage at different life cycle stages.
In this experiment RNAi plasmid library, containing randomly sheared genomic fragments was used to create an inducible library in bloodstream form T. brucei . After transfection, the library was grown under non-inducing and inducing conditions and genomic DNA was isolated from surviving populations.

Cells carrying RNAi target fragments that negatively impact fitness through dsRNA expression and RNAi-mediated ablation are relatively depleted as the population expands and these changes are reported by the depth of sequence coverage relative to the uninduced control (No Tet).

datasetPresenter.name: tcruCLBrenerNon-Esmeraldo-like_Li_Transcriptome_Remodeling_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome during Infection in Human Fibroblasts (NonEsmo aligned)
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome of T. cruzi Y strain during infection of human cells mapped against T. cruzi CL Brener Non-Esmeraldo-like.
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcriptome time course of infection:
Total RNA was isolated from axenic Trypanosoma cruzi Y strain epimastigotes (insect vector stage), extracellular trypomastigotes and from amastigote-containing human fibroblast (ATCC #CRL-2522) monolayers at 6 time points spanning 4–72 hours post-infection (4, 6, 12, 24, 48 and 72hr). Two to four independent biological replicates were sequenced (Illumina HiSeq1000) for each condition, generating 2.7 billion high quality reads (101 bp paired-ends) from 35 samples. Reads are mapped to the T. cruzi CL Brener, T. cruzi CL Brener Non Esmeraldo-like, and T. cruzi CL Brener Esmeraldo-like genomes in TriTrypDB

Samples:
epi: epimastigotes
trypo: trypomastigotes
amas 4hpi: amastigotes 4 hours post-infection
amas 6hpi: amastigotes 6 hours post-infection
amas 12hpi: amastigotes 12 hours post-infection
amas 24hpi: amastigotes 24 hours post-infection
amas 48hpi: amastigotes 48 hours post-infection
amas 72hpi: amastigotes 72 hours post-infection


This data set has a corresponding data set in HostDB that is called "H sapiens Transcriptome during Infection with T cruzi".

datasetPresenter.description: RNA-seq and ribosome profiling of Trypanosoma cruzi DM28c non-infective (epimastigote) and infective (metacyclic trypomastigote) life stages. Sequencing was done using ABI Solid and resulting FASTQ data was mapped to T. cruzi CL Brener in TriTrypDB. Expression results are displayed on ortholog gene pages in T. cruzi CL Brener.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Nilsson_Spliced_Leader_rnaSeqSplicedLeaderAndPolyASites_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Bloodstream and procyclic form spliced leader transcriptomes (427, Antat)(2010)
datasetPresenter.summary: T. brucei bloodstream and procyclic form mRNASeq transcriptomes and Splice Leader Site mapping.
datasetPresenter.description:
Trasncriptomes of T. brucei procyclic and bloodstream forms were produce using Splice Leader Trapping (SLT) - an mRNA sequencing method that simultaneously records transcript abundance and maps 5' splice leader sites. The SLT technique differs from conventional RNA sequencing in that the second strand cDNA synthesis is primed using 5' biotinylated splice leader sequence. For this study, eight samples were analyzed by SLT:

1. Long slender bloodstream form (T. brucei AnTat 1.1)
2. Short stumpy bloodstream form (T. brucei AnTat 1.1)
3. Bloodstream form (T. brucei Lister 427)
4. Procyclic form (T. brucei AnTat 1.1)
5. Alba1 induced RNAi in Procyclic form (T. brucei AnTat 1.1)
6. Alba1 uninduced RNAi in Procyclic form (T. brucei AnTat 1.1)
7. Alba3/4 induced RNAi in Procyclic form (T. brucei AnTat 1.1)
8. Alba3/4 uninduced RNAi in Procyclic form (T. brucei AnTat 1.1)

templateInjector.prop: Samples analyzed: Life cycle stages, RNAi of Alba expression

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Tschudi_Transcriptome_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: RNA sequencing of four Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense YTat 1.1 procyclic form cDNA libraries enriched for 5' or 3' end transcripts. Data is aligned to the T. brucei TREU927 genome.
datasetPresenter.description:
To catalogue the T. brucei 5' and 3' end processing sites, illumina sequencing of 4 procyclic cell cDNA libraries was performed. All libraries were prepared from Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense YTat 1.1 procyclic form cells and the resulting Illumina reads were aligned to the T. brucei TREU927 reference genome.

Samples include:
1. 3' end-enriched, oligo(dT) primed library.
First strand cDNA synthesis was initiated with an oligo(dT) primer on a Poly(A)+ selected RNA template.
2. 3' end-enriched, random hexamer primed library.
First strand cDNA synthesis was initiated with random hexamers on a Poly(A)+ selected RNA template.
3. 5' spliced leader-enriched, random hexamer primed library.
Monophosphated transcripts were removed from Poly(A)+ selected RNA by treatment with Terminator (5'-phosphate-dependent exonuclease) and and first strand cDNA synthesis was initiated with random hexamers. Second strand cDNA synthesis was primed with the spliced leader primer.
4. 5' triphosphate-enriched, random hexamer primed library.
Monophosphated transcripts were removed from Poly(A)+ selected RNA by treatment with Terminator (5'-phosphate-dependent exonuclease). The resulting triphosphated transcripts were treated with phosphatase and ligated with a 5' adapter containing the BpuE I restriction site. First strand cDNA synthesis was initiated with random hexamers and second strand synthesis was initiated with BpuE I restriction site sequence.

templateInjector.prop: T.brucei transcriptome mapping 3prime-end-enriched oligo(dT) primed cDNA, 3prime-end-enriched random primed cDNA, 5prime-SL-end-enriched cDNA, 5prime-triphosphate-end-enriched cDNA

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_microarrayExpression_E-MEXP-2026_DHH1_mutant_pLEW100_24H_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: mRNA profiles of induced DHH1 vs DEAD:DQAD mutant
datasetPresenter.summary: Microarray analysis of T. brucei Lister 427 procyclics under two conditions: overexpressing wild type DHH1 or expressing mutant DHH1.
datasetPresenter.description:
mRNA profiles of overexpressed DHH1 vs mutant
The RNA helicase, DHH1, is necessary for RNA instability under certain conditions in insect stage trypanosomes. This study measured global mRNA expression in T. brucei Lister 427 procyclic cells under two conditions: ~twofold overexpression of wild-type DHH1 and the expression of an ATPase-inactive dhh1 mutant at levels less than the endogenous DHH1.

RNA was prepared from T. brucei Lister 427 procyclic cell lines (carrying inducible expression vectors of mutant or wild-type dhh1) before and after induction with tetracycline for 24 hours. cDNA was synthesized, labeled with dye and hybridized to microarrays (JCVI PFGRC Trypanosoma brucei 19K v3). Uninduced cells were used as control.

templateInjector.prop: DHH1 wild type and DHH1 DEAD-DQAD mutant data versus the control
DHH1 mutant induced vs control=DHH1 mutant induced;wild type induced vs control=wild type induced
DHH1 mutant induced vs control=control;wild type induced vs control=control

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_microarrayExpression_E-MEXP-1476_heat_shock_stress_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Procyclic trypanosomes: heat shock vs untreated control
datasetPresenter.summary: Expression profiles of heat shock treated procyclic trypansosomes compared to untreated control.
datasetPresenter.description:
Expression profiles of heat shock treated procyclic trypansosomes compared to untreated control.

Procyclic stage Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427 cells were incubated at 41°C or 27°C for 60 minutes and analyzed by microarray. Total RNA was labeled with dye and hybridized to microarrays (JCVI PFGRC T. brucei 37K v2). The data represent two biological replicates and 5 technical replicates.

Procyclic trypanosomes (strain 427 lister) were grown in culture under standard conditions at 27°C in SDM79 medium with 10% foetal bovine serume (Brun and Schnenberger, 1979), in a gazed incubator (5% CO2). Logarithmically growing procyclic cells (at about 5*10^6 cells/ml, at 27°C) were added to one volume medium that had been heated to 53°C and incubated at 41°C for 60 minutes in a waterbath in a closed tube (41°C sample). The control cells were added to one volume medium at 27°C and also incubated for 60 minutes in a closed tube at 27°C. Cells were harvested and washed once in PBS. The harvesting was done within 8 minutes.

templateInjector.prop: heat shock data versus the control

datasetPresenter.name: tbruLister427_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Trypanosoma brucei strain Lister 427
datasetPresenter.description: DNA was isolated (Nicolai Siegel and Oliver Dreesen) from cultured bloodstream forms of Trypanosoma brucei strain Lister 427 containing various transgenes, and prepared for single-ended sequencing by Illumina and 454 technologies, which yielded read lengths of 76bp and 350bp (average) respectively. The sequences were assembled (George Cross) using individual chromosomes of the genome reference strain Trypanosoma brucei TREU (Trypanosomiasis Research Edinburgh University) 927/4 as templates and SeqMan NGen software (DNASTAR). The assemblies were evaluated and annotations were transferred from the genome reference strain TREU 927 by Matthew Rogers of The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruEsmeraldo_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence for Trypanosoma cruzi Esmeraldo strain cl3
datasetPresenter.description:
Trypanosome cruzi Esmeraldo strain cl3 represents the TcIIb lineage and was isolated in 1977 from a 20 year-old male patient in acute phase of the Chagas disease patient in Sao Felipe, Bahia State, Brazil. A clonal derivative was prepared from epimastigote culture by plating on blood agar plates (M. Lewis) and used for sequencing.

Total DNA was carefully extracted from cultured late log phase T. cruzi Esmeraldo cl3 epimastigote forms. Genomic DNA depleted of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA (kDNA), was purified and used for sequencing. The gDNA was fragmented and sequenced using the Roche 454 FLX Titanium technology.

##Genome-Assembly-Data-START##
Assembly Method :: Newbler v. March 2012
Assembly Name :: Trypanosoma_cruzi-5.1.3
Genome Coverage :: 60x
Sequencing Technology :: Roche 454
##Genome-Assembly-Data-END##

Please see the T cruzi Esmeraldo cl3 Genbank Record (GCA_000327425.1) for full attributions and credits.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: Please consult with the Principal Investigator before undertaking large scale analyses of this unpublished sequence or annotation.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Ferguson_Phospho_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The phosphoproteome of bloodstream form Trypanonosoma brucei, causative agent of African sleeping sickness.
datasetPresenter.description:
The phosphoproteome of bloodstream form Trypanonosoma brucei, glycosylphosphatidylinositol- specific phospholipase C-null mutant strain RUMP 528.

Bloodstream form T. brucei strain RUMP 528 cells were isolated from infected rats and purified over DEAE-cellulose. Whole cell lysates were enriched for phophopeptides (SCX-TiO2) and analyzed by LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: lbraMHOMBR75M2903_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leishmania braziliensis M2903 Genome sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
The Leishmania brazilensis M2903 strain was isolated in 1975 from a cutaneous lesion of a man who contracted the infection in a forested area of Serra dos Carajas, Para State, Brazil. RT-PCR typing with several primer sets shows that this line lacks detectable levels of LRV1 virus. It is infective in various animal models according to the literature and in work from the Beverley laboratory. Genomic DNA was made by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to minimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA. The gDNA was fragmented and sequenced using the Roche 454 FLX Titanium technology.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_originsOfReplication_McCulloch_Origins_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Origins in replication in T.brucei TREU927 determined by Marker Frequency Analysis, a technique that compares copy number of the marker sequences in replicating and non-replicating cells.
datasetPresenter.description:
Origins of replication in T.brucei TREU927 were determined by Marker Frequency Analysis, a technique that compares copy number of the marker sequences in replicating and non-replicating cells. Origin- proximal sequences will be over-represented compared with origin-distal markers during replication.

Cell Sorting and DNA Sequencing:
Early-mid S phase (replicating) and G2-enriched (non-replicating) populations of PCF T. brucei cells were prepared by cell sorting. Genomic DNA was purified from S-phase and G2- enriched samples and paired-end 100 bp Illumina reads were obtained.

Replication Origin Analysis:
DNA-Seq coverage was compared between the S-phase and G2-phase samples using the following rational. Sequence reads were mapped to the T. brucei TREU927 genome (TriTrypDB release 3.3) using Burrows-Wheeler Aligner. The read-depth data for each position were binned into 2,500 bp sections and the average value across each 2,500 bp bin was used to calculate the ratio of read-depth between the S and G2 samples.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_chipChipExper_McCulloch_Orc1Cdc6_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome wide binding sites of the replication initiator ORC1/CDC6 in T. brucei TREU927 determined by ChIP-chip assay.
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome wide binding sites of the replication initiator ORC1/CDC6 were determined by ChIP-chip analysis.

ORC1/CDC6-bound DNA:
A hemizygous ORC1/CDC6 T. brucei strain was generated in which one allele was deleted and the other modified to encode a Myc-tagged ORC1/CDC6 variant. ORC1/CDC6-bound DNA was crosslinked, immuoprecipitated with antibodies against Myc and then treated with Proteinase K to remove ORC1/CDC6.

Microarray:
Purified ORC1/CDC6-bound DNA was labeled with dye and hybridized to a microarray covering the megabase chromosomes of T. brucei TREU927 using "input" (un-enriched) DNA as control. The NimbleGen Tiling ChIP Service (design ID 19441, design name 090109_Tbru_LM_CHIP) was used: 385,816 probes were tiled across all unique regions of the T. brucei genome at an average spacing of 61 bp.

templateInjector.prop: in called peaks tracks, peaks are colored by score (blue <= 40, green <= 50, orange <= 60, red > 60)

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Gunasekera_Three_Stages_Proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Relative protein abundance-changes in three life stages
datasetPresenter.summary: Potein levels in the long slender (LS), short stumpy (SS) mammalian bloodstream form stages relative to the procyclic (PC) insect-form stage.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Gowthaman_mRNA_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Procyclic and bloodstream form transcriptomes and ribosome profiling
datasetPresenter.summary: Ribosome profiling and mRNA sequencing in animal-derived slender bloodstream forms (T. brucei 927) and insect midgut cultured procyclic forms (T. brucei Lister 427).
datasetPresenter.description:
Ribosome profiling and mRNA libraries were constructed in triplicate from three sources: procyclic form T. brucei TREU927 (PCF), animal-derived in vivo slender bloodstream form T. brucei TREU927 (slBF), and cultured bloodstream form T. brucei Lister 427 (cBF).

Samples include:
1. PCF mRNA : mRNA from in vitro grown T. brucei 927 procyclic forms (3 replicates)
2. PCF riboProf : ribosome footprints from in vitro grown T. brucei 927 procyclic forms (3 replicates)
3. slBF mRNA : mRNA from animal-derived (Wistar rats) T. brucei 927 slender bloodstream forms (3 replicates)
4. slBF riboProf : ribosome footprints from animal-derived (Wistar rats) T. brucei 927 slender bloodstream forms (3 replicates)
5. cBF mRNA : mRNA from in vitro grown T. brucei 427 bloodstream forms (3 replicates)
6. cBF riboProf : ribosome footprints from in vitro grown T. brucei 427 bloodstream forms (3 replicates)

Treatment protocol:
Cells were treated with 100 ug/ml cycloheximide for 2 min at either room temperature (procylic cells) or 37 o (bloodform cells) to arrest elongating ribosomes.

templateInjector.prop:
Translation efficiency is defined as the ratio of ribosome profiling reads to mRNA reads.
PCF mRNA = procyclic form mRNA sequencing
PCF riboProf = procyclic form ribosome profiling
slBF mRNA = slender bloodstream form mRNA sequencing
slBF riboProf = slender bloodstream form ribosome profiling
cBF mRNA= cultured bloodstream form mRNA sequencing
cBF riboProf= cultured bloodstream form ribosome profiling

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Rijo_Circadian_Regulation_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Circadian control of bloodstream and procyclic form transcriptome (AnTat1.1)
datasetPresenter.summary: Bloodstream and procyclic form transcriptomes during a 48-hour time-course of alternating temperatures or at constant temperature.
datasetPresenter.description:
Synchronized Trypanosoma brucei AnTat 1.1 parasites (bloodstream and insect procyclic forms) were probed for circadian regulation of the transcriptome. Parasites were synchronized in vitro for three days using temperature as environmental stimulus. After these three initial days, parasite cultures were either kept in alternating temperatures or maintained at constant temperature and parasite RNA was collected every four hours for two consecutive days. Differentiation of bloodstream forms to procyclic forms was induced by addition of 6mM cis-acconitate and a temperature change from 37 to 28℃. The procyclic forms were subjected to alternating temperature between 23 and 28℃ whereas the bloodstream forms were subjected to temperatures of 32 and 37℃

RNA-sequencing of libraries was performed in HiSeq2000 platform (Illumina) with 50-bp reads according to manufacturers instructions by the Beijing Genomics Institute (BGI).

Samples:
Alternating temperature:
BSF 12 hour intervals at 32 and 37℃ with time points taken every 4 hours
BSF 0, 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, 32, 36, 40, 44, 48 -hr

PF 12 hour intervals at 23 and 28℃ with time points taken every 4 hours
PF 0, 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, 32, 36, 40, 44, 48 -hr

Constant temperature:
BSF at 37℃ with time points taken every 4 hours
BSF 0, 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, 32, 36, 40, 44, 48 -hr

PF at 28℃ with time points taken every 4 hours
PF 0, 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, 32, 36, 40, 44, 48 -hr

templateInjector.prop:
Transcript levels of fragments per kilobase of exon model per million mapped reads (FPKM). Note that Non-Unique reads are ignored in the expression graphs. This means that the expression of duplicated genes (or gene families) might be underrepresented. Please consult the non-unique aligned read tracks in the genome browser to determine if your gene of interest contains non-uniquely aligned reads. The percentile graph shows the ranking of expression for this gene compared to all others in this experiment.
In addition to expression values, the data table of genes determined by the authors to fit a circadian rhythm also contains values that define the circadian rhythm - phase, period, amplitude and associated p-values.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruCLBrener_Teixeira_virulent_avirulent_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Comparative transcriptomes of virulent and avirulent T. cruzi (CLBrener aligned)
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: Transcriptomes of virulent and avirulent T. cruzi determined by RNA sequencing
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparative transcriptomes of virulent and avirulent T. cruzi
datasetPresenter.description: Human foreskin fibroblasts were infected with one of two cloned strains of Trypanosoma cruzi, CL Brener and CL-14, a virulent and avirulent clone, respectively, in biological triplicate. RNA was extracted from the cultures at 60 and 96 hours post infection, and from tissue culture-derived trypomastigotes using Trizol. The samples were DNAse treated and purified using a Qiagen RNeasy mini kit. Poly(A)+ RNA was selected using oligo-dT following Illumina TruSeqv2 instructions, and cDNA libraries were made using a TruSeq RNA Sample Prep Kit Version II with an average insert size of ~300 nucleotides. Libraries were sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 1500.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Mulindwa_Human_Rodent_Comparison_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome of T. brucei rhodesiense from human, rodent, culture
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: TODO: T. brucei rhodesiense from human, rodent, culture
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome of T. brucei rhodesiense from humans and rodents
datasetPresenter.description: The transcriptomes of Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense from blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of human patients was compared with those of trypanosomes from the blood of infected rodents. RNA was purified from human blood using PAXgene tubes and depleted of human rRNA and hemoglobin mRNA. RNA was purified from human CSF using PAXgene tubes or Trizol and depleted of human rRNA. For rodent samples, 8 immunocompetant rats were infected with one of two T.b. rhodesiense isolates that were obtained 1-2 years earlier from the same clinic and had undergone 2 mouse passages. RNA was purified from blood samples using PAXgene tubes and depleted of rRNA. Samples were prepared for sequencing using the Illumina TruSeq Total Stranded RNA preparation kit and sequenced with the Illumina NextSeq500 system at the EMBL Genomics Core Facility. 75 Single-end reads were generated.

datasetPresenter.name: ldonBPK282A1_HTS_SNP_Indian_SOLiD_Isolates_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genomic sequence reads - Indian Isolates
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole genome resequencing data from Leishmania donovani isolates BHU-1095, 39 and 2001, which are known to cause visceral leishmaniasis were used to call SNPs and determine CNV at the gene and chromosome level.
datasetPresenter.description:
Whole genome resequencing data from Leishmania donovani isolates BHU-1095, 39 and 2001 were analyzed for single nucleotide polymorphisms and copy number variation using L. donovani BPK282A1 as a reference.

SNP analysis
Reads are aligned to the reference genome using Bowtie 2 and realigned around indels using GATK. SNPs, indels and concensus sequence are generated with VARSCAN and stored in the database.

CNV analysis
The median read depth is set to the organism's ploidy and each chromosome's median read depth is normalized to this value. Contigs that are not assigned to chromosome are excluded from this analysis. Gene copy number is similarly calculated using a normalized read depth for each gene. To compare the number of genes in the resequenced genome to the reference genome, genes are grouped into clusters that are inferred to have originated by tandem duplication.
Isolate information
These three L. donovani clinical Indian isolates known to cause visceral leishmaniasis.

Isolate 39 was isolated on 28.05.2000 from Muzaffarpur, Bihar from splenic aspirate of a patient who did not respond to SAG therapy. Isolate 2001 was isolated on 01.02.2000, from a patient in Balia, Uttar Pradesh, who responded to SAG therapy. Isolate Ld BHU-1095, responsive to amphotericin B was collected relatively recently from Muzaffarpur in Bihar on 31.07.2010. Splenic aspirates were collected and adapted to culture. Sequencing runs were done using cycled ligation sequencing on a SOLiD Next Generation Sequencer.

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_HTS_SNP_Sequencing_12_Strains_Of_Putative_Hybrids_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genomic sequence reads - 12 strains of hybrids
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole genome resequencing data from 12 strains of hybrids of Leishmania infantum (from a region that reports only cutaneous leishmaniasis) were used to call SNPs and determine CNV at the gene and chromosome level.
datasetPresenter.description:
Whole genome resequencing data from 12 strains of hybrids of Leishmania infantum were analyzed for single nucleotide polymorphisms and copy number variation using L. infantum JPCM5 as a reference.

SNP analysis
Reads are aligned to the reference genome using Bowtie 2 and realigned around indels using GATK. SNPs, indels and concensus sequence are generated with VARSCAN and stored in the database.

CNV analysis
The median read depth is set to the organism's ploidy and each chromosome's median read depth is normalized to this value. Contigs that are not assigned to chromosome are excluded from this analysis. Gene copy number is similarly calculated using a normalized read depth for each gene. To compare the number of genes in the resequenced genome to the reference genome, genes are grouped into clusters that are inferred to have originated by tandem duplication.
Isolate information
Whole genome analysis of population diversity from vector-derived strains. 12 strains of L. infantum that were isolated from a focus of cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) in the Cukurova province of southeast Turkey as part of a large-scale survey of both vectors and patients in this region. There are no visceral leishmaniasis (VL) cases reported in this region. 11 of these 12 CUK strains were isolated from sand flies (specifically Phlebotomus tobbi), while only a single isolate was of human origin.

datasetPresenter.name: ldonBPK282A1_HTS_SNP_Zackay_Genome_Comparison_Ethiopia_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Genome wide comparison of Leishmania donovani strains from Ethiopia
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome wide comparison of Leishmania donovani strains from Ethiopia
datasetPresenter.description:
Whole genomic sequencing (WGS) was carried out for 41 L. donovani strains and clones from VL and VL/HIV co-infected patients in northern Ethiopia/Sudan (NE) (n = 28) and southern Ethiopia (SE) (n = 13). correlation between single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) and geographic origin was seen for 38/41 isolates, separating the NE and SE parasites into two large groups. SNP restricted to NE and SE groups were associated with genes involved in viability and parasite resistance to drugs. Unique copy number variation (CNV) were also associated with NE and SE parasites, respectively.
NE regions: Humera, Metema, Barbar el fugara (Southern Sudan), N/gondar - metema, N/gondar/humera
SE regions: Konso, Negele-borena, Omo Valley

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_HTS_SNP_Weir_Population_Genomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: T. brucei population genomics
datasetPresenter.description: Evolutionary theory predicts that the lack of recombination and chromosomal re-assortment in strictly asexual organisms results in homologous chromosomes irreversibly accumulating mutations and thus evolving independently of each other, a phenomenon termed the Meselson effect. We apply a population genomics approach to examine this effect in an important human pathogen, Trypanosoma brucei gambiense. We determine that T.b. gambiense is evolving strictly asexually and is derived from a single progenitor, which emerged within the last 10,000 years. We demonstrate the Meselson effect for the first time at the genome-wide level in any organism and show large regions of loss of heterozygosity, which we hypothesise to be a short-term compensatory mechanism for counteracting deleterious mutations. Our study sheds new light on the genomic and evolutionary consequences of strict asexuality, which this pathogen uses as it exploits a new biological niche, the human population.

datasetPresenter.name: Pathways_TrypanoCyc_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanocyc is a community annotated Pathway/Genome Database of Trypanosoma brucei
datasetPresenter.description:
Trypanocyc Overview
Trypanocyc is a community annotated Pathway/Genome Database of Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African Trypanosomiasis. Trypanocyc is maintained at the French National Institute of Agricultural Reasearch (INRA) to collect information on the T.brucei metabolism and make it available to the public. TrypanoCyc was built using a collaborative web platform (TrypAnnot) allowing splitting the annotation efforts between a group of experts each one working on his/her pathways of interest. TrypanoCyc improves automatic metabolic network reconstruction by adding developmental-stage and compartment information on enzyme activity. These metadata on the network will help generate tailor-made metabolic networks (e.g. metabolic network of procyclic mitochondria) and help understand the parasite metabolism to a greater extend.

Trypanocyc Annotation
One of the major objectives of the Trypanocyc project is to make it easy for biologists to annotate reactions and provide information regarding the localization of enzyme activity and presence/absence of enzyme activity at various developmental stages of the parasite.

Use in TriTrypDB:
The External Links table on TriTrypDB gene pages contains links to the corresponding record in TrypanoCyc.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_RNASeq_Clayton_mRNADegradation_halfLife_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: mRNA Decay in Bloodstream and Procyclic Forms
datasetPresenter.summary: mRNA decay in T. brucei TREU 927 bloodstream and procyclic forms assayed by mRNA-Seq
datasetPresenter.description:
The decay of T. brucei TREU 927 mRNA in bloodstream and procyclic forms was determined by mRNA sequencing following the application of ActinomycinD.

Bloodstream form (Lister 427, 2T1) and procyclic form (Lister 427) cells were incubated under conditions that inhibit transcription (Actinomycin) with and without trans splicing inhibition (Sinefungin). At various times, RNA was isolated from harvested cells and depleted of rRNA by subtraction. For each time point, mRNA preps were sequenced using Illumina HighSeq and half-life values were calculated.

The Illumina and 454 reads were assembled separately and subsequently merged to produce 38 Mb genome in 27,019 contigs with an N50 of 2307. EuPathDB downloaded the data from GenBank, version Oct 2, 2012.
